To  understand  and  have  basic  knowledge  of  fundamental\nconcepts of law to examine, interpret and evaluate basic legal texts.\n\nCourse Outcome\n\nThe course will help the students:\n 1.  To gain elementary understanding of the scope and purpose of law.\n 2.  To know the various sources of law and to develop an understanding of basic concepts\n     of law\n 3.  To garner skills and acquire knowledge required in legal writing and research.\n\nModule - I: Meaning and Classification of Laws         (Lectures-08)\ni. Meaning and definition\nii. Functions of law\niii. Classification of laws: i. Public and Private Law ii. Substantive and Procedural Law\niv. Municipal and International Law\n\nModule - II: Sources of Law                            (Lectures- 11)\ni. Custom\nii. Precedent\niii. Legislation\n\nModule - III: Basic Concepts of Indian Legal System    (Lectures-12)\ni. Common Law\nii. Constitution as the Basic Law\niii. Rule of Law\niv. Separation of Powers\nv. Judicial system in India\n\nModule - IV: Legal Writing and Research                (Lectures - 09)\ni. Legal materials -Case law\nii. Statutes, Reports, Journals, Manuals, Digests etc.\niii. Importance of legal project/ research\niv. Techniques of Legal project/ research\nv. Legal writings and citations\n\n\n=== Page 88 ===\nSuggesting Readings\n1. State of Punjab, AIR 1955 S.C. 549, 556\n\n\n=== Page 89 ===\nSemester-I\nLB-102                                                                                  Credits: 4\nSubject: Law of Contract- I                                       (Minimum    Lectures-       40)\n\nCourse Objectives\n\nThis course provides the detailed knowledge of the legal principles and rules used to determine\nthe existence of an enforceable agreement. The nature of contract law; the process of formation,\ninterpretation, performance and termination of contracts and remedies will be examined.\n\nThe paper explores the fundamental principles of contract law. It examines the requirements for\nthe  formation  of  a  contract  and  examines  the  agreement,  forms  of  consideration,  formalities,\nprivity  and  capacity.  It  also  considers  the  contents  and  formation  of  a  contract,  including\nexpress  and  implied  terms,  as  well  as  excluding  or  limiting  terms.  The  course  provides  the\nknowledge and skills necessary to pursue contract law further in a more specific way.\n\nCourse Outcome\n\nOn successful completion of this course students will be able to:\n\n1.     Demonstrate an advanced and integrated understanding of the legal framework for contract\n       law, including formation, content and interpretation of contracts in Indian law.\n2.     Gain an understanding of fundamental principles of the law of contract and its impact.\n3.     Identify and apply the elements of contract law required to create an enforceable contract.\n4.     Identify and apply factors which invalidate a contract.\n5.     Apply the required legal principles necessary to discharge a contract.\n6.     Identify and apply the remedies available to a party in case of a breach of contract.\n7.     Make a comparative study between provisions of contract law in India and England.\n8.     Analyse and research complex problems relating to contract law.\n9.     Demonstrate sophisticated cognitive and creative skills in approaching legal issues relating\n       to contract law and generate appropriate responses\n\nCourse Module\n\nModule- I                                                                     (Lecture 10)\n       1.  Meaning and nature of Contract\n       2.  Offer/Proposal\n                i.     Definition\n               ii.     Communication\n          iii.         Revocation\n               iv.     Types\n                v.     Invitation to offer\n       3.  Acceptance\n                i.     Definition\n               ii.     Communication\n          iii.         Revocation\n\n\n=== Page 90 ===\niv.  Tenders/ Auctions\n\nModule - II                                                                                 (Lecture 10)\n\n1. Consideration\n\n  i.            Definitions\n  ii.           Essentials\n  iii.          Privity of Contract\n\n  2.            Capacity to enter into a Contract\n      i.         Minor’s Position\n     ii.         Nature/ effect of minors agreements\n\nModule - III                                                                                (Lecture 10)\n\n            1.    Validity, discharge and performance of contract\n  i.              Free Consent\n  ii.             Coercion, undue influence, Misrepresentation, fraud Mistake\niii.              Unlawful consideration and object\n iv.              Effect of void , voidable, valid , illegal, unlawful, uncertain agreement\n          v.      Discharge of contract\n vi.              Performance of Contract\nvii.              Time and place of performance\n       viii.      Impossibility of performance and Frustration\n ix.              Breach of Contract Anticipatory & Present\n\nModule -IV                                                                                  (Lecture 10)\n\n  1.                 Remedies\n  i.                 Damages\n  a)                 Kinds\n  b)                 Remoteness of Damages\n  ii.                Injunction\n  iii.               Specific Performance\n  iv.                Quantum Merit\n  v.                 Quasi contract\n\nActs\n   1.              Contact Act 1872\n   2.              The Specific Relief Act 1963\n\nSuggested Readings\n   1.              Law of Contract & Specific Relief , EBC Publication , Dr. Avtar Singh\n   2.              Law of Contract & Specific Relief, Allahabad Law Agency, Dr. R. K. Bangia\n   3.              The Indian Contract act, lexis Nexis publication, Sir DinshawFardunjiMulla\n\n\n=== Page 91 ===\n4.  Anson’s Law of Contract, Oxford Publication, J. Beatson, A. Burrows.\n\nEssential Case Laws\n\n1.  Smith v Hughes [1871] 1 LR 6 QB 597\n2.  Hartog v Colin & Shields [1939] 3 All ER 566\n3. English over time\nhas become not only a world-wide common language of communication but also has acquired\nspace  in  all  the  major  spheres  of  life,  and  advocacy  is  not  untouched  from  it.  A  basic\nunderstanding,  speaking  and  writing  ability  of  English  will  not  only  boost  the  morale  of  the\nstudent  but  will  also  propel  his/her  career  to  new  summits  in  this  globalised  era.  Therefore\nEnglish learning will no doubt be helpful in excelling good advocacy skills and lawyer-ship of\nthe individual.\n\nCourse Outcome\n\nThis course is designed to imbue among the students:\n\n 1.  To understand, identify, develop and practice essential English speaking skills during\n     their legal studies and in their everyday life.\n 2.  To appreciate the constituents of good oral and written language\n 3.  To develop techniques to communicate effectively\n 4.  To inculcate amongst student’s courtroom language\n\nModule I: Grammar and Usage                                           (Lectures: 10)\n\n     1.     Tense and Composition\n     2.     Basic Transformations\n     3.     Active/Passive\n     4.     Direct/Indirect Questions\n     5.     Simple, Compound and Complex Sentences\n     6.     Articles\n     7.     Some common errors\n\nModule II: Comprehension and Composition                              (Lectures: 10)\n\n     1.     Reading Comprehension\n     2.     Comprehension of Legal Texts\n     3.     Paragraph and Precis writing\n     4.     Letter Writing- Formal and Informal\n\nModule III: Drafting of Reports and Projects    (Lectures: 10)\n\n1.  Abstracts\n2.  Legal Language\n\n\n=== Page 93 ===\n3.  Legal Maxims\n4.  Foreign Words\n\nModule IV                                                (Lectures: 10)\n1.     Common Hindi and Urdu Words used in Courts\n2.     Translations from Hindi to English and vice-versa\n\nSuggested Readings:\n\n1.  Legal Language and Legal Writing- P.K.Mishra\n2.  English Grammar – Wren and Martin\n3.  Legal Language, Writing and General English – J.S. Singh\n\n\n=== Page 94 ===\nSemester-I\nBBM-105                                                                            Credit: 04\nSubject: Principles and Practices of Management                          (Minimum lectures: 40)\n\nCourse Objectives\nThe  course  aims  at  providing  fundamental  knowledge  and  exposure  to  the  concepts,  theories\nand practices in the field of management.\n\nCourse Outcomes\nOn completion of this course, the students will be able to:\n (a) Understand the concepts related to businesses, principles and practices of management.\n (b) Realize and demonstrate the roles, skills and functions of management.\n (c) Understand  and  apply  the  management  functions  i.e.  planning  organizing,  staffing,\n            directing and controlling.\n (d) Understand the theories and concepts related to motivation, leadership.\n (e) Understand  the  complexities  associated  with  management  of  human  resources  in  the\n            organizations and will be able to handle these complexities.\n\nModule- I: Overview of Management                                           (Lectures - 10)\ni.          Introduction: Concept, nature, process and significance of management.\nii.         Managerial levels, skills, functions and roles.\niii.        Management Vs. Administration.\niv.         Management Science and Art.\nv.          Development  of  management  thoughts:  classical,  neo-classical,  behavioural,  systems\n            and contingency approaches.\n\nModule – II: Planning & Organizing                                          (Lectures - 10)\ni.          Planning: Nature, scope and objectives of planning.\nii.         Types of plans; Planning process; Business forecasting.\niii.        MBO; Concept, types, process and techniques of decision-making;\niv.         Bounded Rationality.\nv.          Organizing: Concept, nature, process and significance.\nvi.         Principles of an organization; Span of Control.\n   vii.     Departmentation.\n  viii.     Types of an organization; Authority-Responsibility.\nix.         Delegation and Decentralization.\nx.          Formal and Informal Organization.\n\nModule – III: Staffing, Motivation & Leadership                             (Lectures - 10)\n     i.     Staffing: Concept, Nature and Importance of Staffing.\nii.         Motivating and Leading: Nature and Importance of motivation; Types of motivation.\niii.        Theories of motivation-Maslow, Herzberg, X, Y and Z;\niv.         Leadership - meaning and importance; Traits of a leader; Leadership Styles.\nv.          Likert's Systems of Management and Managerial Grid.\n\n\n=== Page 95 ===\nModule – IV: Controlling                                             (Lectures - 10)\n     i.     Controlling: Controlling the basis control process – critical control points and standards.\n    ii.     Control as a feedback system.\n   iii.     Real-time information and control, feed forward control.\niv.         Requirements for effective controls.\n     v.     Recent  Trends  in  Management:  Social  Responsibility  of  Management – environment\n            friendly management.\n\nSuggested Readings\n\n1. Stoner, Freeman and Gilbert Jr.; Management, Prentice Hall of India, New Delhi, 2003.\n2. Gupta, C.B.; Management Concepts and Practices, Sultan Chand and Sons, New Delhi, 2003.\n3. Koontz. O Donnel and Weirich (2001) - Management, Tata McGraw Hill Publishing\nCompany,New Delhi.\n4. Chopra, R.K. -Principles & Practices of Management, Sun India Publications, Latest Edition.\n5.  Tripathi  P.C.  and  Reddy  P.N.,  Principles  &  Practices  of  Management,  2  Edition,  Tata\n       McGrawHill.\n\n\n=== Page 96 ===\nSemester-I\nBBM- 106                                                                  Credits: 04\nSubjects: Managerial Economics                                 (Minimum Lectures: 40)\n\nCourse Objectives\n         The  aim  of  every  Business  and  industrial  enterprise  is  to  earn  profit  and  to  sustain  in\nlong. A sound decision requires fair knowledge of the aspects of with knowledge of economic\ntheory  and  tools  of  economic  analysis  are  the  base  for  the  sound  decision.  Since  managerial\neconomics  is  concerned  with  such  aspects  and  tools  of  analysis,  it  is  pertinent  to  the  decision\nmaking process. The objective of this course is to give understanding of the basic concepts and\nissues  in  managerial  economics  and their  application  in  business  decisions.  This  course  deals\nwith micro-economic issues and principles involving  households and firms, at individual level\nmainly their consumption, production, distribution etc. This course has been designed with the\naim of developing a practical approach in managerial decision making with the help of various\nconcepts as Demand analysis, market structure supply and cost concepts.\n\nCourse Outcomes\nAfter completing this course, students will be able to\n 1.      Understand the roles of managers in firms and how they make internal and external\n         decisions.\n 2.      Apply the economic way of thinking to individual decisions and business decisions\n 3.      Analyze real-world business problems with a systematic theoretical framework.\n 4.      Understand the macro variables as inflation and Business cycles and their impact on an\n         economy.\n         .\n\nModule I: Introduction to Managerial Economics                            (Lectures - 06)\n i.      Nature, Scope, Definitions of Managerial Economics,\n ii.     Micro vs. Macro Economics,\n iii.    Application of Managerial Economics to Business, fundamental concepts,\n iv.     Gap between theory & practice and role of managerial economist in a business firm.\n\nModule II:Consumer Behaviour and Demand Analysis                          (Lectures - 12)\n i.      Cardinal Utility Approach: Diminishing Marginal Utility, Law of Equi-Marginal Utility\n ii.     Ordinal Utility Approach: Indifference Curves, Marginal Rate of Substitution, Budget\n         Line and Consumer Equilibrium,\n iii.    Theory of Demand, Law of Demand, Movement along vs. Shift in Demand Curve,\n iv.     Concept of Measurement of Elasticity of Demand, Factors Affecting Elasticity of\n         Demand, Income Elasticity of Demand, Cross Elasticity of Demand.\n v.      Demand forecasting: Demand forecasting meaning, significance and methods.\n\nModule III: Theory of Production, Cost and Firm's Behaviour               (Lectures - 12)\n i.      Meaning and concept of Production, and Production Function,\n ii.     Factors of Production: Fixed and Variable Factors,\n\n\n=== Page 97 ===\niii.    Law of Variable Proportion (Short Run Production Analysis), Law of Returns to a Scale\n         (Long Analysis),\n iv.     Concept of Cost: Short Run Cost,Long Run Cost curves,\n v.      Economics and Diseconomies of Scale,\n vi.     Market structure: Definition, Types of market, market forces and equilibrium, Pricing\n         under Perfect Competition, Monopoly, Monopolistic Competition, Oligopoly.\n\nModule IV: Macro Economic Analysis                                          (Lectures - 10)\n i.      Macro-Economic Variables,\n ii.     Circular flow of income,\n iii.    National Income Concepts, definition and its measurement.\n iv.     Inflation: types and causes,\n v.      Business Cycle: concept, management policies in various stages of Business cycle.\n\nSuggested Readings:\n 1.      Baye, Michael. Managerial Economics and Business Strategy. 9th Edition. Boston:\n         McGraw-Hill Irwin, (2017).Textbook. ISBN: 978-1-259-29061-9\n 2.      Paul G. Keat, Philip K. Y. Young and Sreejata Banerjee, Managerial Economics -\n         Economic Tool for Today’s Decision Makers 6th Ed., Pearson Education, (2013).\n 3.      Christopher R. Thomas and S. Charles Maurice, Managerial Economics: Foundations of\n         Business Analysis and Strategy 10th Edition McGraw- Hills, (2011).\n 4.      Craig H. Petersen, W. Chris Lewis and Sudhir K. Jain, Managerial Economics 5th\n         Edition Pearson Education( 2008).\n 5.      Hirschey Mark – Economics for Managers (Thomson, India Edition, 2007)\n 6.      M.L. Jhingan& J.K. Stephan - Managerial Economics (Vrinda Publications 2nd 9)\n 7.      Mehta, P.L. (2003); Managerial Economics, Sultan Chand & Sons\n 8.      Koutsoyiannis, A. (2003) Modern Micro-Economics, Macmillan Press Ltd.\n 9.      Hirschey Mark – Economics for Managers (Thomson, India Edition, 2007\n\n\n=== Page 98 ===\nSemester- II\n\n\n=== Page 99 ===\nSemester-II\nLB-201                                                                       Credit: 4\nSubject: History- (Legal Developments)                     (Minimum Lectures: 40)\n\nCourse Objective\nThe course is to develop understanding of evolution of modern legal system in India.\n\nCourse Outcome\nThe course will enable the students:\n  1.      To gain elementary knowledge of early legal developments.\n  2.      To attain knowledge about the constitution and establishment of various courts in India\n  3.      To know the historical development of laws including personal laws.\n\nModule I: Early Developments (1600- 1836)                                    (Lectures - 10)\n  i.       Charters of the East India Company: 1600, 1661, 1726 and 1753\n  ii.      Settlements: Surat, Madras, Bombay and Calcutta\n  iii.     Courts: Mayor's Court of 1726 and Supreme Court of 1774\n  iv.      Statutes: Regulating Act, 1773; Pitts India Act, 1784; The Act of Settlement 1781\n  v.       Conflict: Raja Nanad Kumar, Kamaluddin, Patna Case, and Cossijurah f. Warren\n           Hastings: Judicial Plans of 1772, 1774 and 1780 Lord Cornwallis: Judicial Plans of\n           1787, 1790 and 1793\n  vi.      Lord William Bentinck (With special focus on Appraisal of Criminal law)\n\nModule II: Evolution of Law and Legal Institutions                           (Lectures - 10)\n i.        Development of Personal Laws\n ii.       Development of Law in Presidency Towns\n iii.      Development of Civil law in Mufussil: Special Emphasis on Justice, Equity and Good\n           Conscience\n iv.       Codification of Laws: Charter of 1833, The First Law Commission, the Charter of\n           1853, The Second Law Commission\n v.        Establishment of High Courts, 1861\n vi.       Privy Council and Federal Court: Appeals and working of Privy Council, Appraisal of\n           Privy Council, Features of Federal Court\n vii.      Evaluation: Special Reference to Racial Discrimination in the fields of criminal and\n           civil justice\n\nModule III: Legal Profession and Education                                   (Lecture-10)\ni.         Early Developments though Major's Court, Supreme Court, Company's Adalat, High\n           Court, Legal Practitioners Act of 1879, The Chamier and Indian Bar Committer of\n           1951\n ii.        The Advocates Act of 1961: Provisions and Disciplinary powers\niii.        Law Reporting: Theory of Precedents, Features of Law reporting from 1773 to 1950\niv.         Legal Education: History and Basic Aims of Legal Education\n\n\n=== Page 100 ===\nModule IV: Constitutional History                                   (Lectures - 10)\n i.               The Indian Councils Act, 1861\n ii.              The Indian Councils Act, 1892\n iii.             The Indian Councils Act, 1909\n iv.              The Government of India Act 1919\n v.               The Government of India Act, 1935\n\nSuggested Readings\n\n1. M.P. Jain - Outlines of Indian Legal History\n2. V.D. Kulshrehtha - Landmarks of Indian Legal and Constitutional History\n3. J. K. Mittal- Indian Legal History\n4. M.P. Singh - Outlines of Indian Legal and Constitutional History\n5. Abdul Hamid - Constitutional History of India\n6. Irfan Habib-Medieval India I: Researches in the History of India, 1200-1750\n\n\n=== Page 101 ===\nSemester-II\nLB-202                          Credits: 4\nSubject: Law of Contract- II    (Minimum Lectures- 40)\n\nCourse Objectives\n\nThe  main  object  of  the  course  is  to  study  and  understand  the  concept  of  special  types  of\nContracts-  Contract  of  Agency,  Bailment,  Pledge,  Indemnity  and  Guarantee,  law  relating  to\ncertain kinds of specific relief and partnership.\n\nCourse Outcomes\n\n 1.        Understand the basic principles of agency, including who is an agent, liability of principles\n           to  third  parties  in  contract,  the  fiduciary  duties  of  agents,  and  how  those  duties  vary  in\n           magnitude and how breaches vary in terms of severity and the legal consequences.\n 2.        Get  a deep  insight  about  the  law and  procedure  relating  to  contract of  Bailment,  Pledge,\n           Indemnity  and  Guarantee,  Rights,  duties  and  liabilities  of  Bailor,  Bailee,  Pawnor  and\n           Pawnee.\n 3.        Learn about various kinds of equitable reliefs.\n 4.        Gain knowledge about the remedies for persons whose civil or contractual rights have been\n           violated.\n 5.        Understand the basic principles of partnership law, including what is a partnership and who\n           are partners, types of partner and rights and duties of a partner, the fiduciary obligations of\n           partners  to  each  other,  rules  regulating  partnership  property,  the  rights  of  partners  to\n           participate in the management of the partnership.\n 6.        Understand how partnership is different from other forms of business organization\n 7.        Learn about Procedure for registration of partnership.\n 8.        Understand  about  the  Re-constitution  and  Dissolution  of  a  firm  and  formalities  related\n           thereto, Rules upon Dissolution of Partnership, and special features of limited partnerships.\n\nModule I                                                                            (Lecture 10)\nIndemnity and guarantee/ Bailment and pledge\n i.         Meaning, distinction between indemnity and guarantee\n    ii.     Rights/ duties of indemnifier, indemnified and surety\n   iii.     Discharge of surety, kinds of guarantee, bailment and pledge\n iv.        Meaning and distinction\n v.         Rights and duties of bailor/bailee, pawnor/pawnee\n vi.        Lien\nvii.        Termination of bailment\n\nModule II                                                                           (Lecture 10)\nAgency\n i.         Definition of agent and principal, essentials of relationship of agency\n    ii.     Creation of agency: by agreement, ratification and law\n   iii.     Relation of principal/ agent, sub agent, and substituted agent\n\n\n=== Page 102 ===\niv.                 Termination of agency\n\nModule III                                                                               (Lecture 10)\nSpecific relief act 1963\ni.                Recovery of property\nii.               Specific performance of contract\niii.              Injunctions: Temporary and perpetual, mandatory\n\nModule IV                                                                                (Lecture 15)\n1. The Indian partnership act 1932\n2. Nature of partnership firm\n        i.          Relations of partners to one another and outsiders\n     ii.            Rights/ duties of partners inter se\niii.                Partnership property\niv.                 Relations of partners to 3ʳᵈ parties\n        v.          Liability of holding out\nvi.                 Minor as a partner\n          vii.      Incoming and outgoing partners\n3.                  Dissolution\n            i.      By consent\n     ii.            By agreement\niii.                Compulsory dissolution\niv.                 Contingent dissolution\n        v.          By notice\nvi.                 By court\nvii.                Consequences of dissolution\nviii.               Registration of firms and effect of non-registration\nActs\n         1.         Contact Act 1872\n         2.         The Specific relief Act 1963\n         3.         The Indian Partnership Act, 1932\n\nSuggested Readings:\n        1.         Law of Contract & Specific Relief , EBC Publication , Dr. Avtar Singh\n        2.         Law of Contract & Specific Relief, Allahabad Law Agency, Dr. R. K. Bangia\n        3.         The Indian Contract act, lexis Nexis publication, Sir DinshawFardunjiMulla\n        4.         Anson’s Law of Contract, Oxford Publication, J. Beatson, A. Burrows.\n        5.         Indian Partnership Act, Universal Publication, Dr.Madhusudan Sahay\n        6.         Indian Partnership Act, Central law publication, Dr. S. C. Tripathi\n\n\n=== Page 103 ===\nEssential Case Laws\n\n1.  Snow  White  Industrial  Corporation,  Madras  v. Millions  of  jobs  have  been  created  by  IT,  and\nhence, today, it is essential for everyone to understand what information technology is, and how\nit plays a vital role in every aspect of modern-day life. Hence the objective of this course is to\nfamiliarize the students with the basic fundamentals of computer, operating system, networking,\nand use of computers in data processing. The course will help students recognize the importance\nof the information and apply their knowledge and to expose them to the present day capabilities\nand limitations of computers.\n\nCourse Outcomes\nAfter completing this course, students will be able to\n        1.      Understand basic concepts and terminology of computers.\n        2.      Have a basic understanding of personal computers and their operations.\n        3.      Use Internet/Web services as a resource for learning and discovery\n        4.      Be able to identify issues related to information security.\n\nModule - I: Basics of Computer and its evolution                                   (Lectures - 12)\n        i.      Evolution of Computer,\n        ii.     Classification of computer\n        iii.    Computer Generations\n        iv.     Applications of Computer\n        v.      Types of software (System and Application)\n        vi.     Compiler and Interpreter,\n        vii. Generation of Language (Machine Level Assembly, High Level, 4GL),\n        viii.    Number Systems and their Inter conversion.\n\nModule - II                                                                        (Lectures - 8)\nInput and Output Devices:\n i.           Input Devices\n ii.          Output Devices\n iii.         Computer Memory: Primary Memory and Secondary memory\n iv.          Magnetic Disks - Floppy disks, Hard disks, Magnetic Tape,\n v.           Optical disks -CD ROM and it's types (CD ROM, CD ROM-R, CD ROM-EO, DVD ROM\n              Flash Memory\n\nModule III                                                                         (Lectures - 10)\nOperating System Concept:\n        i.      Introduction to operating system; Function of OS, Types of operating systems,\n\n\n=== Page 105 ===\nii.     Booting Procedure, Start-up sequence, Details of basic system configuration, Important\n         terms like Directory, File, Volume, Label, Drive name, etc.\n iii.    Introduction to GUI using Windows Operating System:\n iv.     Management information system: concept and applications\n\nModule IV                                                                   (Lectures - 10)\nConcept of Data Communication and Networking\n          i. Internet, Intranets, Extranets, Inter-networking devices.\n          v.      Web Browsers, Internet Protocols, Search engines, e-mail, Web browsing,\n                  searching, downloading & uploading from Internet.\n          vi.     Artificial Intelligence (AI), Applications of Artificial Intelligence.\n\nSuggested Readings:\n1.  Turban, Rainer and Potter (2003). Introduction to Information Technology. At  the  same  time  an  effective  communication  helps  to  tackle  the  client\ninterviews effectively. Court rulings and legal reasoning need good communication skills so as\nto provide an impressive reading the world wide. Therefore the subject will certainly be helpful\nin excelling communication skills and lawyer-ship of the individual.\n\nCourse Outcome\n\nThis course is designed to imbue among the students:\n\n 1.  Understand,  identify,  develop  and practice  essential  Communication  skills  during  their\n     legal studies and in their everyday life.\n\n 2.  Imbibe among students the intricacies of Client Interviewing.\n\n 3.  Understand methods of Legal Counseling.\n\nModule I: Communication                  (Lectures - 10)\n\ni.   Meaning\nii.  Types and Directions to Communication\niii. Approaches to Communication\niv. Barriers to Communication\nv.   Communication Process\nvi. Channels of Communication\n\nModule - II: Client Interviewing           (Lectures - 10)\n\ni.   Meaning and significance\nii. Different Components: listening, types of questions asked, Information gathering, Report formation, Ethical\nconsideration\n\nModule - III: Legal Counselling            (Lectures- 10)\n\ni.   Definition and its differentiation from general counselling\nii. Different types of counselling\niii. Approaches to Counselling\niv. Training Skills: Simulated exercises\n\n\n=== Page 107 ===\nModule - IV: Legal Reasoning                        (Lectures- 10)\n\ni. What's measurable is almost\nalways presented in the form of statistics. Without the use of statistics the business is virtually\nimpossible.  Statistics  are  used  to  make  a  wide  range  of  decisions  in  business  and.  The\nenvironment  is  highly  complex  and  Business  statistics help  in  taking  sound  decision  in  the\nuncertainty.  Statistics  play  an  important  role  in  business.  A  successful  businessman  must  be\nvery  quick  and  accurate  in  decision  making.  Hence  the  basic  objective  of  this  course  is  to\ndevelop students' familiarity with the basic concepts and tools in statistics so as to enable them\nto resolve complex problems of decision making in business.\n\nCourse Outcomes:\nAfter completing this course, students will be able to\n 1.      Produce appropriate graphical and numerical descriptive statistics for different types of\n         data.\n 2.      Identify statistical tools needed to solve various business problems\n 3.      Develop the skill of performing the calculations needed for various methods of analysis\n 4.      Understand the concept of hypothesis and will also learn various technique of hypothesis\n         testing which will help them to take sound decisions.\n\nModule -I: Overview of Business Statistics                                           (Lectures - 6)\n i.       Definition, important and limitations; Functions and scope of statistics;\n ii.      Types of data;\n iii.     Data collection techniques;\n iv.      Presentation of data- tabulation, charting and diagrammatic\n\nModule - II: Measures of Central Tendency and Dispersion                           (Lectures - 10)\n i.       Central tendency- mean, median, mode, partition values;\n ii.      Variation - range, quartile deviation, average deviation, standard deviation, Lorenz\n          curve; Skegness, moments and kurtosis\n\nModule - III: Correlation and Regression analysis                                  (Lectures - 10)\n            i.      Significance of study of correlation; Correlation and causation;\n            ii.     Types of correlations;\n            iii.    Measurement of correlation (Karl Pearson's methods, Spearman's rank\n                    correlation);\n            iv.     Regression analysis: Difference between correlation and regression; Bivariate\n                    regression model & regression equations of Y on X;\n            v.      Index Numbers; Times series analysis.\n\n\n=== Page 109 ===\nModule - IV: Sampling & Tests of Hypothesis                            (Lectures - 14)\n      i.      Sampling and Sampling Distributions;\n      ii.     Procedure of hypothesis testing; Type I and Type II errors; One tailed and two\n              tailed tests; Testing of hypothesis w.r.t. large samples, about population means,\n      iii.    Difference between means, attributes, population proportion and difference\n              between two proportions; Chi-square test;\n      iv.     Analysis of Variance; Statistical decision making\n\nSuggested Readings:\n 1.  Sharma J K (2014), Fundamentals of Business Statistics, Vikas Pub. House\n 2.  Gupta S P (2013), Statistical Methods, S. Chand & Co.\n 3.  Rubin  &  Levin  (2013),  Statistics  for  Management,  Seventh  edition,  Pearson,  Prentice\n     Hall of India.\n 4.  Kapoor &Sancheti,(2011), Business Statistics, Sultan Chand & Sons\n 5.  Hooda, R.P., Statistics for Business and Economics, 3 ed., Macmillan, N. Delhi.\n\n\n=== Page 110 ===\nSemester-II\nBBM -206                                                                     Credits: 04\nSubjects: Economic Environment of Business                     (Minimum Lectures: 40)\n\nCourse Objective:\nThe  business  operates  in  the  economic  environment  and  is  influenced  by  it.  The  cut  throat\ncompetition has made economic environment more important than ever it has been. Hence the\ncourse has been designed with the purpose of familiarizing the student with various aspects of\neconomic, social, political and cultural environment of India. This will  help them in  gaining a\ndeeper understanding of the environmental factors influencing Indian business organizations.\n\nCourse Outcome:\nAfter completing this course, students will be able to\n\n 1.      Analyze  various  competitive  forces  in  environment  and  to  cope  with  the  changing\n         regulations affecting business and its profitability.\n 2.      Understand various laws and role of SEBI in India.\n 3.      Analyze  various  trends  and  issues  of  Indian  Economy  w.r.t.  Privatization  and\n         Globalization.\n 4.      Understand the monetary and fiscal environment in India and functioning of RBI.\n\nModule - I: Business Environment                                             (Lectures - 8)\n i. Process of environmental scanning,\n v.      Basic philosophies of Capitalism and Socialism with their variants.\n\nModule - II Regulatory Business Laws                                         (Lectures - 12)\n  i. Securities and Exchange Board of India and Investor's Protection.\n\nModule - III New Economic Environment                         (Lectures - 10)\n i.      Liberalization,\n ii.     Privatization\n iii.    Globalization of Indian Economy (trends and issues.)\n iv.     Special Economic Zone (SEZ), their role and impact in Indian Business Environment\n\nModule -IV Monetary And Fiscal Environment In India           (Lectures - 10)\n\n\n=== Page 111 ===\ni.      RBI – Role and functions.\nii.     Regulation of money and credit,\niii.    Monetary and Fiscal Policies,\n\nSuggested readings:\n\n1. In this course, Student\nwill study areas of constitutional law that are essential for an understanding of the fundamental\nconcepts  and  the  unique  complexion  of  the  Indian  constitutional  system.  Student  will  explore\nfederal structure, the separation of powers, and Liability of State.\n\nCourse Outcome\nThis course is designed to create among the students:\n       1.      Demonstrate an advanced and integrated understanding of Constitutional Law.\n       2.      Understand  the  evaluation  and  development  of  the  origin  and  nature  of  Indian\n               Constitution.\n       3.      Analyze the role of State  in transforming  governance  for justice,  social, economic and\n               political.\n       4.      Understanding the procedure of the amendment of the constitution and Basic structure.\n\nModule- I                                                                        (Lectures - 10)\nIntroduction\n       i.      Meaning of Constitution, Constitutionalism and Constitutional Law\n       ii.     Nature of Indian Constitution\n       iii.    Salient features of Indian Constitution\n       iv.     Preamble of the Indian Constitution\n       v.      Citizenship and Status of Non-Residential Indians\n\nModule- II                                                                       (Lectures - 10)\nDistribution of Power between Union and States\n       1. Doctrine of Pith and Substance\n       iv.           Doctrine of Repugnancy\n            v.       Doctrine of Colourable Legislation\n       2.      Residuary Power of Legislation\n       3.      Administrative Powers\n\nModule- III                                                                      (Lectures - 10)\nConstitutional Organs\n1. Union of India (2016) 5 SCC1\n\n\n=== Page 116 ===\nSemester-III\nLB-302                                                                 Credit: 04 Subject:\nLaw of Torts and Consumer Protection Act            (Minimum Lectures: 40)\n\nCourse Objective\n\nThis  module  examines  a  broad  range  of  torts  protecting  a  variety  of  different  interests.  The\nmodule  begins  by  situating  the  law  of  torts  in  relation  to  the  broad  principles  underpinning\ncontract and criminal law; introduces you briefly to the broad range of torts, and then focuses on\nthe fundamental principles of liability with particular reference to negligence. Other torts (e.g.,\nnuisance) are considered, as are current issues of particular difficulty and importance in respect\nof tort law. Students will be encouraged to consider and evaluate the role, nature, and functions\nof tort law, as well as its technical rules.\n\nCourse Outcome\n\nThis course is designed to create awareness and understanding among the students about:\n 1.     The functions of tort law\n 2.     The  basic  principles  relevant  to  other  selected  torts,  e.g.  battery,  and  recognise  and\n        explain their relevance and influence in the key areas studied\n 3.     The basic principles regarding tort remedies, and determine which heads are recoverable\n        in hypothetical problem questions\n 4.     The  areas  of  overlap  between  different  torts,  and  links  between  tort  and  other  legal\n        topics, e.g. contract, human rights, and critically compare their underlying principles in\n        relevant respects\nCourse Module\n\nModule-I- Principles, General Defences and Capacity                    (Lectures - 10)\n\nPrinciples of Tort\n\n        i.      Definition of Tort\n        ii.     Development of Tort actions in England & India\n        iii.    Tort distinguished from Contract & Crime\n        iv.     Constituents  of  Tort-  wrongful   act  (malfeasance, misfeasance, non-feasance),\n                Damage     (damnum     sine injuria &injuria sine damnum),  Remedy  (ubi jus\n                ibiremedium)\n        v.      Mental element in Tort-Malice in Law & Malice in Fact\n\nModule II\n 1.     General Defences of Tort\n        i.      volenti-non-fit-injuria\n        ii.     Necessity\n        iii.    Plaintiff’s default\n        iv.     Act of God\n        v.      Inevitable Accident\n\n\n=== Page 117 ===\nvi.  Private Defense\n              vii. Mistake\n              viii.        Statutory Authority\n              ix.  Doctrine of Sovereign Immunity\n 2.           Capacity – To sue & to be sued: Minor, Judicial and Quasi Judicial acts, Parental & Quasi\n              Parental Authority, Independent & Joint Tort Feasors.\n\nModule III- Consumer Protection                                          (Lectures - 10)\n\n  1.               Introduction\n        i.         Concept of Consumer Sovereignty\n       ii.         Need of Consumer Protection and Consumerism\n  iii.             Doctrine of Caveat Emptor\n  iv.              Consumer Protection & Doctrine of Negligence\n  2.          Salient  Features  and  the  Relationship  of  the  Act  with  Other  Consumer  Protection\n                   Legislations.\nC. Important Definitions under Consumer Protection Act, 2019\n                   i.      Consumer\n                   ii.     Consumer Dispute\n                   iii.    Complaint\n                   iv.     Complainant\n                   v.      Trader\n                   vi.     Manufacturer\n                   vii. Service\n                   viii.          Unfair Trade Practice\n                   ix.     Defect and Deficiency\n                   x.      Restricted Trade Practices\n\nModule IV - Consumer Protection Act                                      (Lectures - 10)\n\n i. Enforcement of Decrees and Order: Dismissal of Frivolous or Vexatious Complaints,\n              Limitation.\n\nSuggested Readings\n\n 1. Aggarwal, V.K.                   -        Consumer Protection Act\n\n\n=== Page 118 ===\nEssential Case Laws\n\n1.  Ashby v. White, (1703) 2 Lord Raym, 932\n2.  Ushaben v. The paper also aims to familiarize with the basic principles\n     of criminal law determining criminal liability and punishment.\n\n     Course Outcome\n     After the completion of the course, students should be able to:\n           1.  Describe  the  basic  principles  of  criminal  law  including  defences,  kinds  of  criminal\n           liability and various theories of punishment.\n           2. Understand case analysis and statutory construction.\n\n     Module- I:\n     Introduction to Substantive Criminal Law                             (Lectures-09)\n     i. Meaning and definition of Crime\n     ii. Fundamental elements of crime: human being, actus reus, mens rea, and injury\n     iii.  Stages in commission of crime: Intention, Preparation and Attempt, commission of crime\n     iv.   Extent, operation and Jurisdiction of IPC\n\n     Module-II:\n     General Explanations and Exceptions                                  (Lectures-10)\n     i. Definition\n     ii. Mistake, Judicial and executive Acts\n     iii. Accident, Necessity, Infancy, Insanity,\n     iv. Intoxication, Consent, Good faith,\n     v.    Private Defence\n\n     Module-III:\n     Different Kinds of Criminal liability under IPC                      (Lectures-12)\n     i. Principles of criminal liability – Individual and Joint Liability\n     ii. Common Intention and Common Object\n     iii. Vicarious Liability\n     iv. Inchoate Crimes: Abetment, Criminal Conspiracy and Attempt\n\n     Module-IV:\n     Punishment                                                           (Lectures-08)\ni.         Theories of Punishment: Deterrent, Retributive, Preventive, Expiatory and Reformative\n          Theory\nii.        The scheme of punishment under IPC:       Fine, Imprisonment, Capital Punishment\n\n\n=== Page 120 ===\nSuggested Readings\n1. Ratanlal&Dhirajlal- Indian Penal Code\n2. H.S. State of Bombay -AIR 1955 SC 287\n27.Haradhan Chakrabarty v. Union of India - AIR 1990 SC 1210\n28.Bimbadhar Pradhan v. State of Orissa -AIR 1956 SC 469\n29.Kehar Singh v. State (Delhi Administrator) - AIR 1988 SC 1883\n30.State of T.N v. Nalini - AIR 1999 SC 2640\n31.C.B.I. v. V.C. Shukla -AIR 1998 SC 1406\n\n\n=== Page 121 ===\nSemester-III\nBBM- 304                                                      Credits: 04\nSubject: Operational Research in Management                   Minimum Lectures: 40\n\nCourse Objectives\n\nThe operation research is a helpful tool in solving complex business problems by mathematical\ntools  in  highly  uncertain  environment.  The  objective  of  this  paper  is  to  develop  students'\nfamiliarity  with  the  basic  concept  and  tools  in  operations  research.  These  techniques  assist\nspecially in resolving complex problems and serve as a valuable guide to the decision makers.\n\nCourse Outcomes\n\nAfter completing this course, students will be able to\n 1.      Understand the basic concept of operation research and its role in decision making\n 2.      Interpret and solve business-related problems with the help of mathematical techniques.\n 3.      Learn solving problem involving limited resources to get the optimum solutions.\n 4.      Identify project goals, constraints and resource requirements in order to achieve project\n         success.\n\nModule- I                                                     (Lectures - 8)\n\nIntroduction to Operation Research\n\n i.      Basic definition, scope, objectives and phases.\n ii.     Models and applications in business decision-making.\n iii.    Limitations of Operations Research.\n iv.     Liner Programming Problem.\n v.      Formulation of LPP.\n vi.     Methods of solving: Graphical and Simplex method.\n vii. Problems with mixed constraints.\n viii. Duality: concept and significance.\n\nModule – II                                                   (Lectures- 12)\n\nTransportation and Assignment problems\n\n         i.      General structure of transportation problem.\n         ii.     Methods for finding initial solution.\n         iii.    Testing optimality using MODI method.\n         iv.     Maximization problem in transportation.\n         v.      Unbalanced Transportation problem.\n         vi.     Assignment problem.\n         vii.    Solution using Hungarian Method.\n         viii.   Solving unbalanced problems, and problems with maximization objective.\n\n\n=== Page 122 ===\nModule – III                                                                     (Lectures - 10)\n\nSequencing and Game Theory\n\n i.      Sequencing Problem-Introduction.\n ii.     Johnson’s method for n Jobs and Two machines, n Jobs and Three Machines. two jobs\n         and m - Machines Problems.\n iii.    Game Theory-Introduction\n iv.     Two-person zero-sum games.\n v.      Games of Pure and mixed strategy.\n vi.     Rule of dominance.\n vii. Graphical solution to games.\n\nModule – IV                                                                      (Lectures - 10)\n\nProject Management and Queuing theory\n\n         i.     Project scheduling-Introduction.\n         ii.    Rules and precautions for drawing the network diagram.\n         iii.   Applications of CPM and PERT techniques in Project planning and control.\n         iv.    Queuing theory-Introduction.\n         v.     Model (M/M/1//F1F0)\n         vi.    Applications of Queue model for better service to the customers.\n\nSuggested readings\n\n                1.  Gupta, S.P. and Gupta, P.K., Quantitative Techniques and Operations Research,\n                    Sultan Chand & Son, Latest Edition.\n                2.  Sharma,  J.K.  (2004),  Operation  Research:  Problems  and  Solutions,  MacMilan\n                    India Ltd 2ndEdition\n                3.  Kothari - Quantitative Techniques (Vikas 1996, 3rd Edition).\n                4.  Sharma J K - Operations Research (Pearson, 3rd Edition)\n                5.  Sharma, S. D., Operations Research, New Edition\n\n\n=== Page 123 ===\nSemester-III\nBBM-305                                                          Credits: 04\nSubject: Financial Accounting                          Minimum Lectures: 40\n\nCourse Objective\n\n The main objective of this course is to familiarize the students with the basic accounting\nprinciples  and  techniques  of  preparing  and  presenting  the  accounts  for  use  of  accounting\ninformation.  Further,  it  aims  at  acquainting  the  student  with  those  significant  tools  and\ntechniques of financial  analysis, which  are  useful  in  the  interpretation  of  financial  statements.\nThese  tools  and  techniques  form  an  important  part  of  management  planning  and  control\nsystems. Thus, the course does not intend to make the students expert accountant.\n\nCourse Outcomes\n\nAfter completing this course, students will be able to:\n 1.  Understand the roles of accountancy and accountants in a business firm.\n 2.  Learn the mechanics of accounting principles and standards.\n 3.  Analyze  real-world  business  accounting  system  with  a  systematic  theoretical\n     framework.\n 4.  Develop analytical ability to make optimal financial decisions for business.\n\nModule -1                                                                      (Lectures - 8)\n\nOverview- Meaning and Scope of Accounting\n\n             i.      Meaning and Scope of Accounting, Need for Accounting.\n             ii.     Branches of Accounting, Accounting and other Disciplines.\n             iii.    Role of Accountant.\n             iv.     Difference between Management Accounting and Financial Accounting.\n             v.      Accounting Concepts.\n             vi.     Accounting Conventions and Principles.\n             vii. Introduction to Accounting Standards Issued by ICAI.\n             viii.    Accounting Equation.\n\nModule -II           Mechanics of Accounting                (Lectures - 10)\n\n i.      Double entry system of accounting.\n ii.     Journalizing of transactions; ledger posting and trial balance.\n iii.    Preparation of final accounts: Trading Account, Profit & Loss Account, Balance Sheet\n         with Adjustments.\n\nModule –IV: Capital and Revenue, Inventory, Depreciation                   (Lectures - 12)\n\n\n=== Page 124 ===\ni. For  effective management  of  people,  it  is  essential  to  perceive  their\nrequirements. Since individuals differ in the behaviour, it becomes very difficult to come with a\nunique  solution  which  can  be  applied  on  all. Organizational Behaviour helps  us  to  study  the\ncomplex  nature  of  human  beings  in  organizations  by  identifying  causes  and  effects  of\nthat behaviour. The  course  aims  to  provide  an  understanding  of  basic  concepts,  theories  and\ntechniques in the field of human behaviour at the individual, group and organizational levels in\nthe changing global scenario.\n\nCourse Outcomes\nAfter completing this course, students will be able to\n 1.      Analysing the behavior of individuals and groups in organizations.\n 2.      To  evaluate  the  reciprocal  relationship  between  the  organizational  characteristics  and\n         managerial behavior.\n 3.      Develop practical insights and problem solving capabilities for effectively managing the\n         Organisational processes\n 4.      To gain better understanding of organization culture and conflicts\n 5.      Developing conceptual understanding of change and its implementation.\n\nModule I                                                                       (Lectures - 08)\n         i.      Introduction: Concept and nature of Organizational behaviour;\n         ii.     Contributing disciplines to the field of O.B.O.B. Models\n         iii.    Need to understand human behaviour; Contemporary challenges\n         iv.     Learning-Nature & significance, Learning Theories\n\nModule II                                                                      (Lectures - 12)\n         i.       Attitudes- Nature & Dimensions of Attitude, Formation Theories, Relationship\n                  between Attitude and Behavior;\n         ii.      Personality - determinants and traits\n         iii.     Perception-Process.\n         iv.      Case Study\n\nModule III                                                                     (Lectures - 10)\nGroup Behaviour & Team Development:\n i.      Nature of Group Dynamics, Types, Stages of Group Formation: The Five Stage Model;\n         Group Structure: Group Tasks\n ii.     Team Development: Concept of Team Vs Group;\n iii.    Types of teams; Building and managing effective teams.\n iv.     Concept of conflict\n\n\n=== Page 127 ===\nv.      Case Study\nModule IV                                   (Lectures - 10)\nOrganization Culture and Conflict Management\n i.       Organization  Culture: Organizational  Culture-Concept,  Functions,  Creating  and\n          sustaining culture;\n ii.      Managing Change; Managing across Cultures; Empowerment and Participation.\n iii.     Management of Crisis,\n iv.      Case Study\n\nSuggested readings\n\nText Books\n       1.  Prasad, L.M.( 2003), Organizational Behaviour, Sultan Chand & Sons.\n       2.  Stephen P., Robbins (2003), Organizational Behaviour; \"Prentice Hall of India\n           Pvt. Ltd.\",New Delhi.\nReference Books\n       1.  Luthans, Fred (2003); Organizational Behaviour, Tata McGraw Hill, New Delhi\n       2.  Chabbra,T.N. & Singh,B.P., Organization Behavior,Sultan Chand & Sons.\n       3.  Khanka, S.S.;  Organizational  Behaviour,  Sultan  Chand  and  Sons,  New  Delhi, Latest\n           Edition.\n       4.  Joseph, Weiss (2004); Organization Behaviour and Change, Vikas Publishing House\n\n\n=== Page 128 ===\nSemester-IV\n\n\n=== Page 129 ===\nSemester-IV\nLB-401                                                                        Credits: 04\nSubject: Constitutional Law – II                                        Minimum Lectures: 40\n\nCourse Objective\n\nThe  Objective  of  this  paper  is  to  provide  understanding  of  concepts  of  State.  In  this  course;\nStudent will study meaning of State, Concept of State Instrumentality. Student will explore the\nmeaning  and  concept  of  Fundamental  Rights  Fundamental  Duties  and  Directive  Principles  of\nState Policies and Emergency provisions.\n\nCourse Outcome\n\nThis course is designed to create among the students:\n 1.      Understand  the  Concept  and  Utility  of  State  and  its  role  in  protection  of  fundamental\n         rights.\n 2.      Understand  the  six  broad  categories  of  Fundamental  Rights  guaranteed  by  the\n         Constitution to its citizens.\n 3.      Understand    the  Fundamental  Duties   that       can  help  the   students  make  their\n         neighbourhood, city, and country better.\n 4.      Analyze the relationship between Fundamental Rights and Directive principles of State\n         Policies.\n\nModule-I                                                                      (Lecture -10)\nFundamental Rights I\n  1.      General\n             i.      Meaning of State, Concept of State Instrumentality\n             ii.     Doctrine  of  Eclipse,  Severability,  Waiver,  Distinction  between  Pre  and  Post\n                     Constitutional Laws\n  2.      Right to Equality\n i.      Right  to  Equality,  Doctrine  of  Reasonable  Classification  and  Principle  against\n         Arbitrariness\n ii.     Reservation/ Protective Discrimination, Issues and Challenges\n\nModule-II                                                                     (Lecture-10)\nFundamental Rights II\n  1.      Right to Freedom\n             i.      Fundamental Freedoms and Reasonable Restrictions\n             ii.     Protections to accused: ex post-facto, double jeopardy and self-incrimination\n             iii.    Protection of Life and Personal Liberty\n             iv.     Right to Education\n             v.      Protection against Arrest and Detention in certain Cases\n\n\n=== Page 130 ===\n2. Right against Exploitation\n               i.      Prohibition of Human Trafficking and Forced Labour\n               ii.     Prohibition of Employment of Children\n\nModule-III                                                                 (Lecture-10)\nFundamental Rights III\n        i.       Right to freedom of religion\n        ii.      Cultural and Educational Rights\n        iii.     Right to Constitutional Remedies: Writs including (Executive writs, Directions and\n                 Orders)\nModule-IV                                                                  (Lecture-10)\nDirective Principles, Fundamental Duties and Emergency Provisions\n      i.        Directive Principle of State Policy and its relationship with fundamental rights\n      ii.       Fundamental Duties\n      iii.      Emergency  Provisions:  Proclamation  of  Emergency;  Failure  of  constitutional\n                machinery and Financial Emergency.\n\nSuggested Readings\nText Books\n\n 37. Further  the\nliabilities which arise under the law torts will be dealt in detail. The student will be able to know\nabout the remedies under the law of torts as well as about Motor Vehicle Act.\nCourse Outcome\nThis course is designed to create among the students:\n         1.      The  key  principles  of  the  torts  of  negligence,  nuisance,  and  the  rule  in  Rylands  v\n                 Fletcher, including principles of liability, limitation and defences; determine answers\n                 to  hypothetical  problems  concerning  these  torts;  and  appreciate  key  decisions  in\n                 these torts.\n         2.      The basic principles relevant to other selected torts, e.g. battery, and recognise and\n                 explain their relevance and influence in the key areas studied\n         3.      The  basic  principles  regarding  tort  remedies,  and  determine  which  heads  are\n                 recoverable in hypothetical problem questions\n         4.      Knowledge about the Motor Vehicle Act\nModule I                                                                        (Lectures -  10)\nSpecific Torts\n\n i. Negligence, Contributory Negligence, res ipsa loquitor, Nervous Shock\n\nModule II                                                                       (Lectures - 10)\nLiability\n i.      Vicarious Liability\n ii.     Strict Liability\n iii.    Trend towards Absolute Liability\n iv. It will help the students to build up and refine decision-making skills so that they\ncan help organizations effectively.\n\nCourse Outcomes\nAfter completing this course, students will be able to:\n 1.      Understand the skills set required for today’s HR professionals.\n 2.      Understand the importance of staffing decisions including recruitment and selection.\n 3.      Understand, implement and evaluate different types of training methods.\n 4.      Differentiate between performance and potential appraisal.\n 5.      Know the common HR practices.\n\nModule I                                                                     (Lectures - 10)\nOverview of HRM\n i.      Introduction: Concept, nature, scope, objectives and importance of HRM.\n ii.     Evolution of HRM; Challenges of HRM.\n iii.    Personnel Management vs HRM.\n iv.     Strategies  for  the  New  Millennium:  Role  of  HRM  in  strategic  management;  Human\n         capital; Emotional Quotient; Mentoring; ESOP.\n\nModule II                                                                    (Lectures - 10)\nHuman Resource Planning\n i.      Acquisition of Human Resources: HR Planning.\n ii.     Job analysis - Job description and job specification.\n iii.    Recruitment - sources and process; Selection Process - tests and interviews; Placement\n         and Induction.\n iv.     Job Changes - transfers, promotions/demotions, separations.\n v.      Discipline and Grievance Procedures: Definition, Grievance Handling Procedure.\nModule III                                                                   (Lectures - 8)\nTraining & Development\n i.      Training and Development: Concept and importance of training.\n ii.     Types of training; methods of training.\n iii.    Design of training programme; evaluation of training effectiveness.\n iv.     Executive development -process and techniques; career planning and development.\nModule IV                                                                 (Lectures - 12)\nPerformance Appraisal & Compensation\n i.      Compensation  and  Maintenance:  Compensation:  job  evaluation  -  concept, process  and\n         significance.\n\n\n=== Page 136 ===\nii.     Components of employee remuneration - base and supplementary.\niii.    Performance and Potential appraisal - concept and objectives.\niv.     Traditional and modern methods, limitations of performance appraisal methods.\nv.      360 degree appraisal technique.\n\nSuggested Readings\n1.      Rao, V.S. P. (2004), Human Resource Management, Test and Cases, Excel Books.\n2.      Aswathappa, K. (2003), Human Resource and Personnel Management (Text and Cases),\n        Tata McGraw Hill Publishing Company, New Delhi\n3.      Chhabra,  T.  N  (2003),  Human  Resource  Management;  Dhanpati  Rai  and Co.  Pvt.  Ltd\n        New Delhi.\n4.      Flippo, Edwin B., Personnel Management, Tata McGraw Hill, latest edition.\n5.      Desler, Gary, Human Resource Management, Prentice Hall, latestedition.\n6.      D'  Cenzo,  David,  A  &  Stephen  P.  Robbin,  Personnel  Human  Resource  Management,\n        Prentice Hall of India, latest edition.\n\n\n=== Page 137 ===\nSemester-IV\nBBM- 405                                                                    Credits: 04\nSubject: Marketing Management                                 Minimum Lectures: 40\n\nCourse Objectives\n\nMarketing  is  one  of  most  frequently  used  word  in  business  words  list  but  perhaps  not  fully\nunderstood by the common man. Most people tend to confuse it with sales or see it as a function\nof selling only. Sometimes it is said that by intelligent marketing technique, the average product\ncan be sold. Thus marketing management is core function of the organization. The course aims\nat  making  students  understand  concepts,  philosophies,  processes  and  techniques  of  managing\nthe marketing operations of a firm.\n\nCourse Outcomes\n\nAfter completing this course, students will be able to\n 1.      Comprehend basic marketing concepts and the marketing environment.\n 2.      Understand various planning and pricing strategies.\n 3.      Understand and Analyzing Business/ Consumer Markets.\n 4.      Develop understanding of various promotion and advertisement techniques.\n 5.      Understand various functions of intermediaries.\n\nModule I                                                      (Lectures - 8)\nIntroduction to Marketing\n i.      Meaning,  Nature  and  Scope  of  Marketing,  Marketing  Philosophies,  Marketing\n         Management Process, Concept of Marketing Mix,\n ii.     Market  Analysis:  Understanding  Marketing  Environment,  Consumer  and  Organization\n         Buyer  Behavior,  Market   Measurement;      Market  Segmentation,  Targeting       and\n         Positioning.\n\nModule II                                                     (Lectures - 10)\nProduct Planning and Pricing\n i.      Product Concept; Types of Products; Major Product Decisions; Product Life Cycle, New\n         Product Development Process;\n ii.     Pricing Decisions; Determinants of Price; Pricing Process, Policies and Strategies.\n\nModule III                                                    (Lectures - 10)\nPromotion and Distribution decisions\n i.      Communication  Process; Promotion  Tools-Advertising,  Personal  Selling,  Publicity  and\n         Sales Promotion;\n ii.     Distribution  Channel  Decisions-Types  and  Functions  of  Intermediaries,  Selection  and\n         Management of Intermediaries.\n\n\n=== Page 138 ===\nModule IV                                                               (Lectures - 10)\nMarketing Organization and Control\n i.      Concept of marketing planning and control, Emerging Trends and Issues in Marketing -\n         Consumerism,\n ii.     Rural Marketing,\n iii.    Social Marketing;\n iv.     Direct and Online Marketing,\n v.      Green Marketing.\n\nSuggested Reading\n\n 1.      Kotler,  Philip.  (2003),  Marketing  Management:  Analysis,  Planning,  Implementation\n         &Control, Prentice  Hall of India.\n 2.      Michael,  J.  E.,  Bruce,  J.  W.  and  Williom,  J.  S.  (2004). Accordingly,  the  objective  of  the  course  is  to  acquaint  the  students  with  the\noverall framework of financial decision- making in a business unit.\n\nCourse Outcomes\nAfter completing this course, students will be able to:\n 1.      Understand the importance of management of finance in a firm.\n 2.      Understand  the  internal  and  external  financial  decisions  to  be  made  by  finance\n         managers.\n 3.      Critically analyze the financial positions of business houses with a logical reasoning.\n 4.      Develop analytical skills to take optimal financial decisions by integrating the concepts\n         of finance, accounting and statistics.\n\nModule I                                                               (Lectures - 10)\nFinancial Management- An Introduction\nFinancial Management:\n i. Methods of Financial Management\n vi.     Organization of Finance\n vii. Functions of Finance\n\nSources of Financing:\n i.       Classification of Sources of Finance\n ii.      Security Financing\n iii.      Loan Financing\n iv.       Project Financing\n v.        Loan Syndication- Book Building\n\nNew Financial Institutions and Instruments:\n i.       Depositories\n ii.      Factoring\n iii.     Venture Capital\n iv.      Credit Rating\n v.       Commercial Paper\n vi.      Certificate of Deposit.\n\n\n=== Page 140 ===\nModule II                                                          (Lectures - 10)\nMoney Valuation and Capital Structure\nConcept in Valuation:\n i. Meaning, Capital Structure and Financial Structure\n  ii.     Patterns of Capital Structure\n  iii.    Optimum Capital Structure, Capital Structure Theories\n  iv. General Techniques:\n                           i.     Risk adjusted discount return\n                          ii.     Certainty equivalent coefficient\n\n 4. Standard deviation\n              iv. Having  an  understanding  of  major  schools  of  legal  theory  which  have  influenced  the\n       development of Western legal tradition and the Indian legal system.\n2.     Prepare  and  present  cogent  arguments  both  orally  and  in  writing  and  make  productive\n       contributions in providing critical analysis of problems and questions.\n\nModule I                                                                       (Lectures-08)\nIntroduction\n       i. Linkage between Jurisprudence and other sciences\n\nModule II                                                                      (Lectures-12)\nSchools of Jurisprudence - I\n       i. The Course Cover areas of family law relating to the concept of Family.\nEvolution of family law and source of Hindu law and Muslim law, their school. The course also\ncovers  the  institutions  of  marriage  under  both  Hindu  and  Muslim  law  and  grounds  of\nmatrimonial remedies. The course is designed to analysis and discuss the above issues of Hindu\nand Muslim law comparatively and separately both.\n\nCourse Outcomes\n\nThe student will be able to analyse various provision of Hindu and Muslim law, their sources,\nconcept of marriage, and various matrimonial remedies available in case of a legal dispute under\nboth Hindu and Muslim law and are able to develop social, moral and ethical values in family\nmatters.\n\nModule I                                                                  (Lectures: 10)\n\n1.      Introduction of Family Laws\ni.       What is family? Characteristics of family, Evolution of Family Law, What is family law?\n         Different personal law for different communities\nii.      Historical development of Hindu and Muslim Law, Codification of Hindu law\n2.      Sources of Hindu Law: Ancient Sources – Shrutis & Smritis, Commentaries & Digest,\n        Custom. Modern Sources – Judicial Decisions, Legislations, Equity, Justice and Good\n        Conscience\n3.      Sources of Muslim Law:   Primary Sources – Quran, Sunnat, Ahadis, Ijma, Qiyas.\n        Secondary Sources – Custom, Judicial Decision, Legislation, Equity, Justice and Good\n        Conscience\n\nModule II                                                                      (Lectures: 10)\n\ni.      Schools of Hindu Law: Mitakshra School of Law and Dayabhaga School of law.\nii.     Schools of Muslim Law: Sunni school of law and Shia school of law\niii.    Application of Law: Who is a Hindu and who is a Muslim?\n\nModule III                                                                     (Lectures: 10)\n\n        1.  Marriage under Hindu Law\ni.      Nature of Hindu Marriage\nii.     Definition and Forms of Marriage\niii.    Degree of Prohibited relationship and Sapinda relationship\niv.     Grounds for Void & Voidable Marriage\nv.      Registration of Marriage\n        2.  Marriage under Muslim Law\n\n\n=== Page 145 ===\ni.      Nature of Muslim marriage\n  ii.     Kinds of marriage\n  iii.    Essentials of valid marriage\n  iv.     Conditions and impediments of Muslim Marriage\n  3.      . Difference between Hindu & Muslim Marriage\n  4.      . Distinction between Shia & Sunni Law of Marriage\n\nModule IV                                                                     (Lectures: 10)\n\n i.       Dissolution of Marriage: Judicial Separation & Restitution of Conjugal Rights\n\n ii.      Dissolution  of  Marriage  under  Hindu  Law:  Theories  of  Dissolution  of  Marriage,\n          Grounds of Divorce &Wife’s Special Grounds for Divorce, Divorce by Mutual Consent,\n          Irretrievable Breakdown of Marriage\n\n iii.     Dissolution  of  Marriage  under  Muslim  Law:  Essentials  of  Talaq,  Modes  of  Talaq,\n          Judicial  Separation  under  the  Dissolution  of  Muslim  Marriage  Act,  1939,  Distinction\n          between Shia & Sunni Law of Divorce.\n\nSuggested Readings\n\n  1. Its\nmain object is to acquaint the students with the various stages through which a civil case passes\nthrough, and the connected matters. Civil Procedure Code is a procedural law which is applied\nof  daily  the  courts  and  lawyers.  Every  law  student  should  have  knowledge  of  civil  procedure\nwhen he goes out to practice as a lawyer. Though, it is true that one gains expert knowledge of\ncivil procedure through  experience.  However,  it  is  necessary to  have a  good understanding of\nthe subject before one enters the profession. The course also includes law of limitation, which\nfixes a period within which a case has to be filed.\n\nCourse Outcomes\nAt the conclusion of the course, students will be able to:\n 1.         Understand the fundamental principles of Civil Procedure Code.\n 2.         Identify the stages of a civil lawsuit.\n 3.         Read and apply a statutory provision or rule in civil proceedings.\n 4.         Demonstrate familiarity with how to draft a document for submission to a court.\n 5.         Recall and apply the law relevant to choosing a court and initiating and responding\n            to a suit.\n 6.         Analyse  and  canvass  procedural  issues  arising  from  disputes  such  as  parties,\n            jurisdiction, forum, governing law and applicable rules.\n 7.         Identify a lawyer’s professional obligations at each stage in a civil suit.\n 8.         Elucidate principles of Alternative Dispute Resolution.\n 9.         Devise  an  appropriate  course  of  action  and  apply  appropriate  court  rules  and\n            procedures in the legal system to reach an expeditious resolution for a range of civil\n            disputes.\n 10. Recognize the importance of accuracy, timeliness, and attention to detail in the legal\n            profession.\n\nModule I                                                                       (Lectures -10)\nIntroduction\n          i.       Definitions:  Decree,  Judgement,  Order,  Foreign  Court,  Foreign  Judgement,\n                   Mesne Profits, Affidavit, Suit, Plaint, Written Statement\n         ii.       Important  Concepts:  Res  Sub-Judice,  Resjudicata,  Restitution,  Caveat,  Inherent\n                   powers of court\n Initial steps in a suit\n            i.     Jurisdiction and Place of suing\n         ii.       Institution of suit\n iii.              Pleadings: Meaning, object, General rules\n iv.               Plaint and written statement\n          v.       Amendment of pleadings\n\n\n=== Page 148 ===\nvi.           Discovery, Inspection and Production of Documents\n     vii.      Appearance and Non-appearance of Parties\n\nModule II                                                        (Lectures - 10)\n Interim Orders\n  i.           Commissions\n ii.           Arrest before judgement\n iii.          Attachment before judgement\n iv.           Temporary Injunction\n v.            Interlocutory orders\n vi.           Appointment of Receiver\n vii.          Security of costs\n\n Suits in Particular Cases\n  i.           Suits by or against Government\n ii.           Suits by Indigent persons\n iii.          Interpleader Suit\n iv.           Summary Procedure\n v.            Suits relating to public nuisance\n\n Module III                                                      (Lectures - 10)\n Judgement and Decree\n  i.           Judgement : Essentials, Pronouncement, Contents, and Alteration\n ii.           Decree : Essentials, Types, Drawing up of a decree, Contents of Decree\n\n Execution\n  i.           Courts by which a decree may be executed\n ii.           Questions to be determined by executing court\n iii.          Payment under Decree\n iv.           Application for Execution\n v.            Modes of Execution\n vi.           Stay of Execution\n\n Module IV                                                       (Lectures - 10)\n Appeals\n  i. Computation of Limitation\n\n\n=== Page 149 ===\niii.     Acquisition of Ownership by Possession\n     iv.      The Schedule – Period of Limitation\nAct and Code\n      i.      The Code of Civil Procedure, 1908\n      ii.     The Limitation Act, 1963\nSuggested readings\nText Books\n 1.  Civil  Procedure  (CPC)  with  Limitation  Act,  1963,  EBC  Publication,  Justice  C. The students will be able to identify, explain and apply the principles of administrative law\n     covered in the course.\n 2. Understand the basic concepts of values and ethics.\n 2.      Understand how values and ethics are relevant in business world\n 3.      Understand why CSR is important for corporate houses\n 4.      Understand corporate governance and its pillars.\n\nModule I                                                                  (Lectures - 10)\nOverview of CSR\n i.      Evolution, Need for CSR; Theoretical perspectives.\n ii.     Corporate  citizenship;  Business  practices;   strategies   for  CSR;  challenges    and\n         implementation.\n iii.    Social responsibility of a business firm.\n iv.     Social responsibility of business stakeholders.\n\nModule II                                                                  (Lectures - 10)\nInternational Frame work for CSR\n i.      International framework for corporate social responsibility.\n ii.     Millennium development goals, Sustainable development goals.\n iii.    CSR as a strategic business tool for sustainable development.\n\nModule -III:                                                               (Lectures - 10)\nCorporate Ethics\n i.      Business Ethics: Definition, Characteristics and Significance.\n ii.     Ethical  Theories  and  Approaches;  Causes  of  Unethical  Behavior;  Ethical  Principles;\n         Levels and Types of Ethical Dilemmas, Cross-Cultural Ethical Dilemmas.\n iii.    Values and Value Systems, Business Ethics in Indian Perspective.\n\nModule IV                                                                  (Lectures - 10)\nCorporate Governance\n i.      Evolution of corporate governance; Governance practices and regulations.\n ii.     Structure and development of boards\n iii.    Role of capital market and government; Governance ratings.\n iv.     Future of Governance – Innovative practices; Good corporate governance.\n\n\n=== Page 154 ===\nSuggested Readings\n\n1.  Hartman Laura P.& Chatterjee Abha, “Perspectives in Business Ethics”, Tata McGraw\n    Hill.\n2.  Velasquez, Manuel G., “Business Ethics – Concepts and Cases”, PHI Publications.\n3. V., “Business Ethics”, Vrinda Publications.\n\n\n=== Page 155 ===\nSemester V\nBBM-506                                                                               Credits: 04\nSubject: Entrepreneurship Development and Small Businesses\n                                                             Minimum Lectures: 40\n\nCourse Objectives\nThe  course  aims  at  providing  fundamental  knowledge  and  exposure  to  the  concepts,  theories\nand practices in the field of entrepreneurship. The course aims to equip students with the basics\nof entrepreneurship and small scale businesses.\n\nCourse Outcomes\nAfter completing this course, students will be able to\n1.     Understand the importance of entrepreneurs and SSIs in country like India.\n2.     Understand what problems are faced by an entrepreneur.\n3.     Understand  the  government  policies  regarding  the  promotion  of  entrepreneurs  and  small\n       scale industries.\n4.     Understand that how an entrepreneur can seek financial help for his enterprise from agencies\n       like NABARD, SIDBI.\n\nModule I                                                                        (Lectures - 10)\nOverview of Entrepreneurship\n       i.      Meaning,  Definition  and  Concept  of  Enterprise,  Entrepreneur  and  Entrepreneurship\n               Development,\n       ii.     Evolution of Entrepreneurship in India, Role of Entrepreneurship in Indian economy and\n               developing economies with reference to self-employment development.\n       iii.    Theories of Entrepreneurship, Traits and skills of entrepreneur.\n       iv.     Entrepreneurs Vs Professional Managers, Problems faced by entrepreneurs.\n\nModule II : Environment Scanning & Women Entrepreneurship                             (Lectures  -10)\n\n                i.      Entrepreneurial  Development,    Entrepreneurial  Culture,  Factors    affecting\n                        Entrepreneurship in India,\n                ii.     Entrepreneur Vs. Intrapreneur, Social Enterprise and Entrepreneurship,\n                iii.    Significance and role of environment, Environmental analysis,\n                iv.     Women Entrepreneurship: Meaning, Characteristics/ features, Problems faced by\n                        women  entrepreneurs  in  India,  Measures  taken  for  the  development  of  women\n                        entrepreneurs in India.\nModule III                                                                          (Lectures - 10)\nProject Management and Small Scale Industries\n                i.      Project  Management-Defining     Business  Idea,  Search  for  business  idea,\n                        Transformation of idea into reality, Business Planning Process, Project appraisal,\n                        Plant location and Plant layout.\n\n\n=== Page 156 ===\nii.         Environmental  Analysis  -  Search  and  Scanning,Identifying  problems  and\n             opportunities\n iii.        Small industry setup, Steps in starting a small industry, incentives and subsidies\n             available, export possibilities\n iv. Role  of  Government-Role  of  Central  Government  and  State  Government  in\n             promoting Entrepreneurship, MSME policy in India.\n ii.         Agencies for Policy Formulation and Implementation-District Industries Centers\n             (DIC),  Small  Industries  Service  Institute  (SISI), Entrepreneurship  Development\n             Institute  of  India   (EDII),  National  Institute  of  Entrepreneurship  &  Small\n             Business  Development  (NIESBUD),National  Entrepreneurship  Development\n             Board (NEDB)\n iii.        Agencies  for  Financial  Support-Role  of  Commercial  banks  and  financial\n             institutions like SIDBI, NABARD,SFCs, and other NBFCs.\n\nSuggested Readings\n\n1.     Joseph A.
