Performance of Contract\n\nModule -II: Sale of Goods Act: Right of parties and remedies                    (Lectures – 10)\n     i.     Unpaid Seller:\nii.         Meaning and Definition\niii. Remedies for breach of contract\n\nModule- III: Negotiable Instruments Act 1881                                    (Lectures- 10)\n     i. Negotiation and Assignment\n\n  Module- IV: Negotiable Instruments Act: Presentation and Liability     (Lectures- 10)\n      i.       Presentation of Negotiable Instruments\n     ii. The  course  aims  to  acquaint  the\n students  with  the  nature,  scope  and  dimensions  of  business  policy  and  strategic  management\n process.\n\n Course Outcomes\n After completing this course, students will be able to:\n             1.   Understand the meaning and need of strategic management.\n             2.   Understand the complexities of strategic management.\n             3.   Understand how the strategies are made.\n             4.   Understand  the  role  of  environmental  scanning  and  SWOT  analysis  while  strategy\n                  making.\n\n Module-I: Introduction to Strategic Management                             (Lectures - 08)\n         i.       Strategic Management, Strategic Planning, Strategic Planning and Strategic\n                  Management.\n          ii.     Strategic Management Process\n         iii.     Formulation Phase: vision, mission, environmental scanning, objectives and strategy\n iv.              Implementation Phase: strategic activities\n         v.       Basic Model of Strategic Decision Making.\n\n Module-II: Environmental Analysis                                          (Lectures - 10)\n i.               Need, Characteristics and categorization of environmental factors, Approaches to the\n                  environmental scanning process - structural analysis of competitive environment; ETOP\n                  a diagnosis tool.\n      ii. Corporate Capabilities - Functional Area Profile and Resource Deployment Matrix\n iv.              Strategic Advantage Profile; SWOT Analysis.\n\n Module-III: Formulation of Strategy                                        (Lectures - 12)\n i.               Approaches to Strategy formation; Major Strategy Options - Stability, Growth and\n                  Expansion, Diversification, Retrenchment, Mixed Strategy.\nii.               BCG Model, GE 9 Cell, Stop-Light Strategy Model\n iii.             Porter’s Model: 5 Force and Porters Diamond Model, Strategic Choice.\n\n\n=== Page 169 ===\nModule-IV: Corporate Development                         (Lectures - 10)\ni. The  objective  of  this  paper  is  to  focus  on  concept  and  classification  of\nproperty as well as principles governing transfer of immovable property.\n\nCourse Outcomes\n\nOn completion of this course:\n\n  1.           The  students  will  be  able  to understand  the  most  fundamental concept  in  property law\n               including easement and registration.\n  2.           The  students  will  be  able  to  appreciate  the  significance  of  property  law  from  various\n               perspectives including economic efficiency, underprivileged perspectives.\n  3.           The students will able to develop skills for applying technical rules of property transfer.\n\nModule-I: General Principles Relating to Transfer of Property            (Lectures - 10)\n\n i.            Interpretation Clause: Movable and Immovable property, Instrument, Attestation,\n               Registration, Notice, Actionable claim\n ii.           Difference between Movable and Immovable property\niii.           Meaning and elements of Transfer of property\n iv.           What kinds of property can be transferred\n v.            Restriction on alienation of property\n vi.           Restriction on enjoyment of property\n    vii.       Transfer to an unborn person\n   viii.       Rule against perpetuity\n ix.           Vested and Contingent interest\n x.            Rule of Election\n\nModule-II: General Principles Governing Transfer of Immovable Property\n                                                                         (Lectures10)\n  i.           Transfer by ostensible owner\n  ii.          Rule of feeding the grant by estoppel\n  iii.         Doctrine of Lis pendens\n  iv.          Fraudulent transfer\n  v.           Rule of part performance\nModule III- Specific Transfers of Immovable Property                     (Lectures-12)\n 1.         Sale:\n            i. Meaning and essentials,\n\n\n=== Page 171 ===\nii. Rights and liabilities of buyer and seller\niii.     Marshalling by subsequent purchaser\n\n 2.      Mortgage:\n  i.      Meaning,\n  ii.     Essentials and kind of mortgage,\n  iii.    Right to redeem,\n  iv.     Right to foreclosure or sale\n  v.      Doctrine of marshalling and contribution\n  vi.     Doctrine of subrogation\n  vii. Charge\n 3.      Lease:\n  i.      Meaning and essentials,\n  ii.     Determination of Lease\n  iii.    Difference between lease & License\n 4.      Gift:\n i.       Meaning and essentials,\n ii.      Gift how made\niii.      Onerous gift,\niv.       Universal done.\n\nModule IV-Indian Easement Act& Registration Act         (Lecture- 08)\n  i.      Definition of Easements\n  ii.     Kinds of easement\n  iii. Amrit Kaur Vs Recovery Officer AIR 2012 NOC 418.\n\n\n=== Page 173 ===\nSemester-VII\n\nLB-702:                                                                             Credit:04\nPublic International Law including Conflict of Laws    (Minimum Lectures: 40)\n\nCourse Objective\n\nThe Public International Law (PIL) Program introduces students to the principal treaties\nand  case  law  within  international  law  and  calls  upon  them  to  consider  the  context  at  hand  in\nfactual  situations.  In  order  to  be  able  to  apply  their  knowledge  to  contemporary  problems,\nstudents  are  given  insight  as  to  the  interaction  between  international,  regional,  and  national\njurisdictions,  the  impact  of  non-legal  systems  such  as  politics  and  economics,  and  the\nconsequences of fragmentation of international law into specialized sub-fields. Further students\nwill be taught Conflict of Laws, also sometimes called Private International Law, is concerned\nwith what happens in cases where not all of the facts are tied to one jurisdiction.\n\nCourse Outcome\nThis course is designed to create among the students:\n1.           Students  attain  in-depth  knowledge  of  the  sources  of  international  law  (treaties  and\n             customary  international  law),  subjects  of  international  law  (identifying  rights  and\n             obligations  of  States,  IOs,  NGOs,  individuals),  the  institutional  framework  (UN,  WTO,\n             regional  agencies,  etc.)  and  dispute  resolution  framework  (courts,  arbitration  tribunals,\n             conciliation, as well use of sanctions and force).\n2.                 Students address contemporary real world issues such as: how the rule of law is upheld at\n             the  international  level,  processes  such  as  “internationalization  of  national  law”  and\n             “constitutionalization of international law”.\n3.           Explain, summarise and apply the conflict of laws rules;\n4.           Apply the conflict of law rules to solve complex conflicts of laws problems in the form of a\n             take-home exam.\n\nModule- I                                                                      (Lectures - 10)\nIntroduction\n\n       1.     Definitions, Nature and Subjects of the International Law.\n       2.     Relationship between International Law and Municipal Law\n              Theory: Monism, Dualism, Delegation & Specific Adoption Theories\n       3.     Sources of International Law\n       i.     Custom\nii.           Treaties\niii.          General Principles of Law Recognized by the Civilized States\niv.           General Assembly Resolutions\nv.            Juristic Works\nvi.           Judicial Decisions\n\n\n=== Page 174 ===\nModule II – Extradition, Recognition and Asylum                     (Lectures - 10)\n           1.     Extradition\n       i. Legal & Retrospective Consequences of Recognition\n   iv.            Withdrawal of Recognition\n\n             3.   Asylum\n       i.         Meaning\n    ii.           Rights of Asylum\n   iii.           Types of Asylum\n\n   Module III - Law of Sea and State Succession                        (Lectures - 10)\n\n             1.   Law of Sea\n       i. The course\nhas  been  designed  in  such  a  manner  that  law  students  could  be  well  acquainted  with  the\nconcepts correlated to investment and various aspects of competition law.\n\nCourse Outcome\n\nThis paper covers a wide spectrum of investment and competition laws with the aim to:\n\n 1.      To familiarize the students with the basic concepts of investment, corporate finance and\n         competition.\n 2.      To  help  them  analyse  various  legal  provisions  relating  to  insolvency,  competition  law\n         and other related laws.\n 3.      To acquaint them with the recent developments in the area of investment law.\n 4.      To help them understand the inter-relationship between law and economics.\n\nModule-I:                                                                 (Lectures- 10)\n\nIntroduction\n\ni.       Concepts of Corporate Law\n ii.     Corporate Personality\niii.     Sources of Corporate Finance: Shares and Debentures\niv.      Issue and Buy Back of Shares\n\nModule- II:                                                               (Lectures-10)\n\nCorporate Re-Structuring\ni.       Conceptual Understanding of Corporate Re-Structuring\n ii.     Modes of Re-Structuring\niii.     Manner of Re-Structuring\niv.      Role of Courts\nModule-III:                                                               (Lectures-12)\n\nInvestment Laws\ni.       SEBI Act, 1992\nii.      Foreign Exchange Management Act, 1999\n\n\n=== Page 177 ===\niii.     Bilateral Investment Treaties\niv.      Foreign Direct Investment\nModule- IV:                                           (Lectures-10)\n\nCompetition Law\n\ni.        Background\nii.       Prohibitions\niii.      Competition Commission of India\niv.       Competition Appellate Tribunal\n\nSuggested Readings\n\n 1.      Guide to Competition Law: Containing Commentary on the Competition Act, 2002 by S\n         M Dugar (Set of 2 Volumes), LexisNexis, 2016.\n 2.      Competition Commission Cases- A compendium of CCI Cases from 2009-2016 by K K\n         Sharma, LexisNexis, 2016.\n 3.      Competition  Law  in  India:  Policy,  Issues,  and  Developments  by  T.  Ramappa,  Oxford\n         University Press.\n 4.      Capital Markets & Securities Laws by Siddhartha Sankar Saha, 2ⁿᵈ ed., Taxmann.\n 5.      Taxmann’s Student’s Guide to Economic Laws.\n 6.      Capital Market and SEBI Regulations, by Tapash Ranjan Saha, Excel Books.\n 7.      Bilateral  Investment  Treaties:  History,  Policy,  and  Interpretation  (1ˢᵗ ed.),  by  Prof.\n         Vandevelde, Oxford University Press.\n\n\n=== Page 178 ===\nSemester-VII\nLB-704                                                                         Credits: 04\nSubject: Land Law (Including U. P. Revenue Code)                  Minimum Lectures- 40\nCourse Objectives\n\n                The objective of this paper is to focus on land reforms in the state of U.P. and make\nstudents  familiar  with  the  provisions  of  U.P.  Revenue  Code  and  U.P.  Panchayati  Raj  Act\n1947, U.P. Consolidation of Holdings Act, 1953.The course provides the detailed knowledge\nof  land  law  reforms,  broad  concept  of  agriculture,  relationship  between  land  and  man,\nconcepts  and  applications  including  analysis  of  tenure  holders,  their interests,  rights  and\nliabilities,  ownership,  possession,  succession,  surrender,  abandonment,  mortgage,  lease  and\nthe  use  of  modern  techniques  for  demarcation  and  digitilisation  of  Revenue  Records  and\nprocedure  of  the  Revenue  Courts.  It  also  deals  with  consolidation  of  holdings,  mutation\nproceedings and local authorities at village level.\n\nCourse Outcomes\nOn successful completion of this course students will be able to:\n\n ∑       Explain  the  notion  of  agricultural  land  and  apply  land  law  concepts  relating  to  tenure\n         holders,  ownership,  possession,  succession,  surrender,  abandonment,  mortgage,  lease\n         and tenancies.\n ∑       Learn about maintenance and revision of village records.\n ∑       Learn about consolidation proceedings, mutation proceedings and its effect.\n ∑       Gain knowledge about the concept of land revenue and its assessment.\n ∑       Understand about the procedure of Revenue Courts and remedies in case of any illegal\n         encroachment.\n ∑       Get a deep insight about the management of land and other property by local authorities.\n\nModule- I                                                                      (Lecture 10)\n\ni.       General overview of Land Laws\n ii.     Special features & Object of U.P. Revenue Code, 2006\niii.     Definitions(Section- 4 of U. P. Revenue Code)\niv.      Gram Sabha : Definition, Constitution, Function\nv.       Gram Panchayat : Definition, Constitution, Function\nvi.      Bhumi Prabhandak Committee : Definition, Constitution and its Functions\n\nModule - II                                                                    (Lecture 10)\n\ni.       Classes of Tenure Holder\n ii.     Rights of Tenure Holders\niii.     Ejectment\niv.      Mutation\n\nModule - III                                                                   (Lecture 10)\n\ni.       Lease, Surrender and Abandonment\n ii.     Management and Allotment of Land by Land Management Committee\niii.     Devolution\n\n\n=== Page 179 ===\niv.   Land Revenue\n\nModule -IV                                                                     (Lecture 10)\n\n      i.     Revenue Courts and Revenue Authorities\n   ii. Consolidation\n               a      Definition\n               b      Declaration, Notification & Effect of Consolidation\n               c      Preparation and Enforcement of Consolidation Scheme\n               d      Close of Consolidation Operations\n\nSuggested Readings\nActs:\n               1. WahidAli VsDirector of Consolidation, 1982 RD 45\n\n\n=== Page 180 ===\nSemester-VII\nLB-705                                                                              Credit:04\nSubject: Environmental Law                                      Minimum Lectures: 40\n\nCourse Objectives\n       Since the inception of human history, environment has played a vital role in sustaining\nlife  and  catering  to  the  needs  of  human  beings  and  various  other life forms.  However,  in due\ncourse  of  time,  man  has  swayed  by  desire  of  greater  industrialization,  urbanization  and\nmodernization  causing  immense  environmental  pollution,  environmental  degradation  and  the\nover-exploitation  of  natural  resources.  It  is  for  these  reasons  that  different  legal  measures  at\ninternational  and  national  level  for  protection  of  environment  have  emerged.  Today,\nEnvironmental  Law  is  one  of  the  most  important  tools  for  environment  protection  and\nmanagement  and  hence  it  is  necessary  for  Law  Students  to  understand  this  multidisciplinary\nsubject.\nCourse Outcomes\n ∑     To familiarize the students with the overall environmental legal regime of the country as\n       well  as  its  international  obligations  and  would  further  equip  the  students  with  basic\n       knowledge and skills to understand environmental issues.\n ∑     To  make  the  students  aware  about  the  provisions  under  the  Indian  Constitution  for\n       protection  of  environment  and  the  various  legislative  measures.  It  also  provides  an\n       opportunity to the students to understand the activist role played by Indian Judiciary in\n       protection of environment and evolution of different principles.\n ∑     A spirit of inquiry to explore the development of Indian environmental law and various\n       legislations and its application in India for the protection of environment.\n ∑     Awareness  regarding  the  problem  of  environmental  pollution  and  Law  as  a  means  of\n       prevention of environmental pollution and protection of environment.\n ∑     Students  will  get  the  knowledge  about  the  Environment  (protection)  Act,  powers  of\n       central government and state government to make laws and Environment Tribunals.\n\nModule- I: Environmental  Law:  International  and  National  Perspective   (Lectures - 10)\n\n1.      Introduction:Meaning, Definition and Concept  of Environment - Components of\n        Environment, Biosphere and Ecosystem, Types of Environment.\n2.      Concept of Pollution – Sources of Pollution, Types of Pollution, and Effects of Pollution.\n3.      International Principles on Environmental Law\ni.       Sustainable Development -Meaning and Scope\nii.      Precautionary Principle\niii.     Polluter pays Principle\niv.      Public Trust Doctrine\n4.      Constitutional Provision\ni.      Right to Wholesome Environment - Evolution and Application\n\n\n=== Page 181 ===\nii.      Development  of  Fundamental  Right  to  Environment  -  Judicial  Role,  Expansion  of\n         Locus  Standi,  Constitutional  Remedy  for  Protection  of  Environment,  Dynamic\n         Interpretation of Article 21, 14 & 19 of the Constitution\niii.     Environment Protection through Public Interest Litigation\n\nModule II: Prevention and Control of Water and Air Pollution             (Lectures - 10)\n\n1. . The Water (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, 1974\ni. Water Pollution - Definition\nii. Central and State Pollution Control Boards - Constitution, Powers and Functions\niii. Water Pollution Control Areas\niv. Sample of effluents -Procedure; Restraint order\nv. Consent requirement - Procedure, Grant/Refusal, Withdrawal\nvi. Citizen Suit Provision\n2. . Air (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, 1981\ni. Air Pollution - Definition\nii. Central and State Pollution Control Boards - Constitution, Powers and functions\niii. Air Pollution Control Areas\niv.  Consent  Requirement  -Procedure,  Grant/Refusal,  Withdrawal  v.  Sample  of  effluents  -\n   Procedure\nv. Restraint order\nvi. Citizen Suit Provision\n\nModule-III:  Protection of Forests and Wild Life                      (Lectures - 10)\n\nA.  Protection of Forest\n    i. Importance of Forest, its kinds and the need for its Conservation\n   ii. Indian Forest Act, 1927 and its Salient Features\niii. Forest Conservation Act, 1980 and its Salient Features\niv. Judicial Approach for Forest Conservation.\n\nB.  Protection of Wild Life\n    i.      The Wild Life (Protection) Act, 1972\n    ii.     Authorities to be appointed and constituted under the Act\n    iii.    Sanctuaries and National Parks, Licensing of Zoos and Parks\n    iv.     Hunting of Wild Animals and other Offences against Wild Life\n    v.      Protection of Specified Plants\n    vi.     Trade or Commerce in wild animals, animal articles and trophies and its prohibition.\n\nModule-IV: General Environmental Legislations     (Lectures - 10)\n\n1. Environmental (Protection) Act, 1986\ni. Meaning of 'Environment', 'Environment Pollutant', 'Environment Pollution'\nii. Powers and Functions of Central Government\n\n\n=== Page 182 ===\niii. Citizen Suit Provision\n2. Principle of 'No fault' and 'Absolute Liability'\ni. Public Liability Insurance Act, 1991\nii. The National Environment Tribunal Act, 1995\n4.  National Green Tribunal Act 2010- An Appraisal\nSuggested Readings:\n\n1. ShyamDiwan, Armin Rosencranz,Environmental Law & Policy in India.\n2. P. Leelakrishnan,Environmental Law in India.\n3. This  paper  is  divided  into  two  parts:  Labour  Law  I  and\n   Labour  Law  II.  Trade  Union  Act,  Industrial  Employment  Standing  Orders  Act  and  Industrial\n   Disputes Act are the major legislations which have been put in Labour Law I to establishes the\n   industrial relationship in the country and protect the workers against exploitation by employers.\n\n   Course Outcome\n\n            1.         The  students  will  be  able  to  understand  the  legal  provisions  of  the  Trade  Union  Act,\n                       1926.\n            2.         To familiarize the students with the need for providing uniform statutory conditions of\n                       service  in  the  form  of  certified  Standing  orders  under  the  Industrial  Employment\n                       (Standing Orders) Act.\n            3.         The  Students  will  be  able  to  understand  the  settlement  of  industrial  disputes  through\n                       conciliation, voluntary arbitration and compulsory adjudication.\n\n   Module -I: Trade Union Act 1926                                              (Lectures - 10)\n\n           i. Collective bargaining\n   Module- II: The Industrial Employment (Standing Orders) Act, 1946                    (Lectures - 10)\n\n     i. Every\nperson is affected by trade related activities either directly or indirectly. Hence, with that aspect\nin mind this course has been designed with the purpose to familiarize the students with the basic\ntenants of Corporate Law and develop their legal acumen to analyse the provisions of law.\n\nCourse Outcome\n\nThe proposed outcome of this course is as follows:\n\n 1.  To  acquaint  the  students  with  the  legal  provisions,  guidelines  and  case  laws  on  the\n     subject of corporate law.\n 2.  To familiarize them with the procedure of documentation for a company.\n 3.  To inform the students of their rights and duties under the Companies Act.\n 4.  To develop the ability to efficiently identify and apply the provisions of law in realistic\n     scenarios.\n\nModule-1: Formation, Registration and Incorporation of Company              (Lectures-10)\n\n           i. The students will be able to understand the concept of wages, the provisions of regular\n         and  prompt  payment  of  wages  and  to  prevent  unauthorized  deductions  and  arbitrary\n         fines from the wages.\n 2.      The  student will  be  able  to  understand  the  measures  which  can  used  to  tackle  income\n         and  labour  market  inequality  including  social  transfers,  and  creating  an  enabling\n         environment for sustainable enterprises.\n\nModule- I:  Minimum Wages Act, 1948                              (Lectures - 10)\n\ni. Authority- Appointment and Powers under the Act.\nvii.     Penalties and punishment for certain Offences;\n\nModule -II: Payment of Wages Act, 1936                           (Lectures - 10)\n\ni.       Object, scope and application of the Act\nii.      Definition of wage\niii.     Responsibility for payment of wages\niv.      Fixation of wage period\nv.       Time of payment of wage\nvi.      Deductions which may be made from wages\nvii.     Maximum amount of deduction\n\nModule-III: Workmen's Compensation Act, 1923    (Lectures - 10)\n\ni. Leela Vs State of Kerela (2004) 102 KLT 207.\n\n\n=== Page 190 ===\nSemester VIII\nLB-804                                               Credits: 4\nSUBJECT: Alternate Dispute Resolution System         Minimum Lectures: 40\n\nCourse Objective\n\nThe  Alternate  Dispute  Resolution  mechanism  evolved  against  the  conventional  method  of\ndispute  settlement  by  courts.  Over  the  years,  individuals  and  corporations  have  realized  the\nadvantages of adopting various ADR mechanisms against the conventional method of litigation.\nTherefore, the importance of this paper has increased in leaps and bounds and so the purpose of\nthis  paper  is  to  ensure  that  students  get  insightful  knowledge  about  this  emerging  area  in  the\narena of dispute resolution.\n\nCourse Outcome\n\nThis course tends to achieve the following out comes:\n\n 1.  To  ensure  that  students  are  well  acquainted  with  the  various  methods  of  dispute\n     resolution.\n 2.  To familiarize them with the various legal provisions and case laws relating to the paper\n     ADR.\n 3.  To develop their legal acumen so that they can help their clients and society select and\n     employ the most effective, just and human methods of dispute settlement.\n\nModule-I                                             (Lectures-8)\nIntroduction\n  i.         Concept of ADR\n ii.         History of ADR\n iii.        Legal Service Authority Act\n iv.         Ombudsman- Lok Pal and Lokayukta\n    v.       Lok Adalat\n\nModule-II                                            (Lectures-10)\nArbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996\n  i.         Definitions\n ii.         Arbitration Agreement\n iii.        Arbitral Tribunal\n iv.         Conduct of Proceedings\n v.          Arbitral Awards\n\nModule-III                                           (Lectures-8)\nEnforcement of Foreign Award\n  i.         New York Convention\n ii.         Geneva Convention\n\nModule-IV                                            (Lectures-8)\nConciliation\n\n\n=== Page 191 ===\ni.      Definitions\nii.      Appointment of Conciliator\niii.     Role of Conciliator\niv.      Conciliation Proceedings\n\nSuggested Readings\n\n1.  International Dispute Settlement by J.G. Merrills, (6ᵗʰ ed.), Cambridge University Press,\n    2017.\n2.  Alternate Dispute Resolution by Madabhushi Sridhar, (1ˢᵗ ed.), LexisNexis Publication.\n3.  Law  and  Practice  of  Alternate  Dispute  Resolution  in  India-  A  Detailed  Analysis  by\n    Anirban Chakraborty, LexisNexis Publication, 2016.\n4.  Law Relating to Arbitration and Conciliation by  P C Markanda, Naresh Markanda and\n    Rajesh Markanda, (9ᵗʰ ed.), LexisNexis Publication, 2016.\n5.  Law of Arbitration and Conciliation (Set of 2 Volumes) by Justice R S Bachawat, (6ᵗʰ\n    ed.), LexisNexis Publication, 2017.\n6.  Arbitration and Conciliation, C R Dutta, LexisNexis Publication.\n\n\n=== Page 192 ===\nSemester VII\nLB-805:                                                                         Credit: 04\nSubject: Interpretation of Statutes and Principle of Legislation\n                                                              (Minimum Lectures: 40)\n\nCourse Objective\n\nStatutory  interpretation  is  the  process  by  which  legislative  instruments  are  given  meaning  so\nthat they  can be understood and applied. This subject will systematically examine the body of\nlaw  that  is  relevant  when  determining  the  intention  of  Parliament  as  expressed  in  legislative\ninstruments.  The  rules,  approaches  and  practices  required by  statute  or developed  at common\nlaw are considered and applied to both state and  federal legislation.  In addition to developing\nstudents? interpretation skills the subject will also focus on legal research and opinion writing.\n\nCourse Outcome\nOn successful completion of this course, a student will be able to:\n1. Know what are the techniques adopted by courts in construing statutes.\n2. The importance of the law making process in the present context\n3. What are the matters to be reckoned with by legislature while enacting laws?\n4.  Understand  and  analyze  the  judicial  interpretation,  construction  of  words,  phrases  and\nexpressions.\n\nModule I – Introduction & General Principles of Interpretation            (Lectures - 10)\n\ni.       Meaning and scope of Interpretation\n ii.     Difference between interpretation and Construction\niii.     litera legis and litera logic\niv.      Harmonious Construction\nv.       Mischief Rule\nvi.      Golden Rule as a modification of Literal Rule\n\nModule II – Aids of Interpretation & Operation of Statutes                (Lectures - 10)\ni.       Internal Aids to the Interpretation\n ii.     External Aids to the Interpretation\niii.     Meaning of Statute and Legislation\niv.      Prospective and Retrospective operation of Statutes\nv.       Amendment and Repeal of Statutes\n\nModule III – Strict Construction of Statutes & Interpretation of Constitution\n                                                                          (Lectures - 10)\ni.       Interpretation of Taxing Statute\n ii.     Interpretation of Penal Statute\niii.     Interpretation of the Constitution\n\n\n=== Page 193 ===\nModule IV – Maxims of Interpretation                                 (Lectures - 10)\n    i.       ut res magis valeat quam pereat\n    ii.      noscitur a sociis\n    iii.     ejusdem generis\n    iv.      Expressio unius est Exclusio alterius\n    v.       Contemporanea Exposito Est Optima et fortissimo in lege\n    vi.      The General Clauses Act, 1897\n\nSuggested Readings:\n1.        Maxwell\n2.        Mathur, D. N.\n3.        Bhattacharya, T.\n4.        Singh, G.P.\n5.        Bindra, N.S. -\n6. In  order  to\nmaintain that efficiency it is necessary that the legal minds of this country are well acquainted\nwith  the  diverse  socio-economic  conditions  here.  Keeping  that  goal  in  mind,  this  course  has\nbeen designed in such a manner so as to ensure that the students are well versed with the basic\ntenants of direct and indirect tax and apply that knowledge in the legal career in years to come.\n\nCourse Outcome\n\nThe following are the proposed outcome of this course:\n\n 5.          To  acquaint  the  students  with  the  legal  provisions,  guidelines  and  case  laws  on  the\n             subject of tax law.\n 6.          To  familiarize  them  with  the  procedure  of  filing  income  tax  returns  and  the  basic\n             concepts of Goods and Service Tax Act, 2016.\n 7.          To inform the students of their rights and duties under the Income Tax Act.\n 8.          To develop the ability to efficiently identify and apply the provisions of law in realistic\n             scenarios.\n\nModule I                                                    (Lectures-10)\nIntroduction\ni. Kinds of insurance and the body regulating the insurance sector will also be taught.\n\nCourse Outcome\n\n 1. Haring and Eveanly- General Principles of Insurance\n\n\n=== Page 198 ===\nSemester VIII\nLB-8063                              Credits: 04\nSubject – International Trade Law    (Minimum Lectures- 40)\n\nCourse Objective\n\nThe objective of the course is to introduce the subject to the students with special reference to\nIndia’s role and place in the multilateral trading represented by the WTO. In this course students\nwill study both international trade, the exchange across national borders of goods, services and\nfactors, and the impact of this trade on domestic and global economies, the significant pressures\nin  the  world  economy  and  the  proliferation  of  regional  trade  arrangements  in  various parts of\nthe world. A special emphasis in this course is placed on trade issues in developing economies\nand the close relationship between direct investment and international trade.\n\nCourse Outcomes\nStudents will acquire theoretical knowledge and will be expected to have:\n\n ∑     Gained  a  knowledge of  where  international  trade  fits  in our  national  economy  and  the\n       global  economy,  through  the  review  of  several  basic  concepts  in  economics  and\n       international economics;\n ∑     Acquired a broad basis in the concept of global trade and its rationale;\n ∑     Developed an understanding of the process of globalisation of production and markets,\n       with international trade as a major component of this process;\n ∑     Gained  an  insight  into  the  main  trade  policy  instruments  implemented  by  various\n       governments  of  the  world  with  a  view  to  exercising  their  stabilisation  role  in  the\n       operation of their national economies;\n ∑     Acquired  comprehension  of  recent  trends  in  international  trade  in  goods  and  services\n       and the main reasons for such trends;\n ∑     Developed some mastery in assessing the impact of government trade policies on trade\n       flows at national and company level;\n ∑     Gained an understanding of multilateral and regional trade arrangements, as well as the\n       international financial framework in which small and large firms operate;\n ∑     Developed  a  better  knowledge  about  the  process  of  regional  trade  integration\n       confronting developing countries;\n ∑     Acquired a deeper awareness of the direct relationship between foreign direct investment\n       and international trade, and;\n ∑     Developed  competencies  that  will  allow  students  to  contribute  to  the  formulation  of\n       appropriate trade strategies.\n\n\n=== Page 199 ===\nModule –I                                                                 (Lecture 10)\n\ni.       Historical introduction of WTO\n ii.     General agreement on tariffs and trade ( GATT)\niii.     World Trade Organisation (WTO)\niv.      Agreement on Agriculture\nv.       Agreement on technical barriers to Trade\n\nModule – II                                                               (Lecture 10)\ni.       Agreement on sanitary and Phytosanitary measures\n ii.     Anti-dumping Agreement\niii.     Agreement on safeguards\n\nModule – III                                                              (Lecture 10)\ni. US- Gasoline case Ds2\n\n\n=== Page 200 ===\nSemester VIII\n    LB-8064                                                            Credit-04\n    Subject- Election Law                                       (Minimum Lectures- 40)\n\n    Course Objective\n    This  course  will  examine  the  law  -  constitutional  and  statutory  governing  the  political  and\n    electoral  process  in India.  The  main  object  is  to  acquaint  the  students  with  the  election  laws\n    governing the elections to the Houses of the Parliament and the State legislatures as well as to\n    the offices of President and Vice-President, analyze lacuna within among the election law and\n    available remedies and to suggest reformation in present election law and procedure.\n\n    Course Outcomes\n    Students graduating with Election Law will be able to:\n     ∑     Understand and identify the importance of election in a democratic country.\n     ∑     Develop a critical thinking about the development of this branch of law.\n     ∑     Gain  knowledge about the existing  legal framework of elections to various democratic\n           bodies.\n     ∑     Critically analyse the present regime of laws with reference to the postulate of free and\n           fair elections as the fundamental point of democracy\n     ∑     Learn the process of development and reforms in the field of election laws.\n\n    Module - I:                                                        (Lectures 10)\n     1. Unionof India, AIR 1991 SC 1745\n7.  S.R. Bommai v. Union of India, AIR 1994 SC 1918\n8.  A.C.Jose v. Sivan Pillai and others, AIR 1984 SC 921\n9.  Kanhiya Lal Omar v.R.K.Trivedi, AIR 1986 SC 111\n10. Guru Gobinda Basu v. Shankari Prasad, AIR 1968 SC 254\n11. Joti Prasad v. Kalka Prasad, AIR 1962 All. 128\n12. Ashok K. Bhattacharya v. In ethics, he is\nguilty if he only thinks of doing so.\n\n         This  course  is  designed  with  a  main  purpose  of  making  law  students  on  the  verge  of\ncompleting their law course to get acquainted with, analyze and critically examine such rules of\nprofessional ethics and conduct. The legal philosophy underlying professional ethics, the rights\nand  concomitant  duties  of  Advocates  and  the  role  played  by  Bar  Councils  in  regulating  legal\nprofession  will  be  the  core  Module  of  the  course.  Furthermore,  the  knowledge  of\nresponsibilities  and  sanctions  is  indispensable  for  an  advocate  to  have  a  better  professional\ncareer, especially in the present era.\n\nCourse Outcomes\n\nThis paper covers a wide spectrum of lawyers’ conduct with aim to:\n\n1. To familiarize the students with the legal provisions, guidelines, and judicial decisions on the\nsubject of professional conduct for lawyers.\n\n2. To acquaint them with the opinions of the Bar Council of India on professional misconduct.\n\n3.  To  inform  students  of  their  Rights  as  advocates,  the  concomitant  duties  and  limitations\nthereof.\n\n4. To develop the ability to efficiently identify ethical issues and dilemmas in realistic scenarios,\nand to propose well-reasoned and articulate resolutions to those issues and dilemmas.\n\nModule I                                                           (Lectures-6)\n\ni.       Introduction: The concept of Professional Ethics in Law\n ii.     Brief History of Legal Profession in India\niii.     The need and necessity of ethics in the legal profession\nModule II                                                          (Lectures-10)\n\nThe Advocates Act, 1961\n\ni.       Bar Councils\n ii.     Functions of State Bar Councils and Functions of Bar Council of India\niii.     Admissions and Enrollment of Advocates\niv.      Types of Advocates: Senior and other Advocates\n\n\n=== Page 205 ===\nv.       Disqualification\n    vi.      Right to Practice\n    vii.     Conduct of Advocates and Disciplinary Proceedings\n\n    Module III                                              (Lectures-10)\n\n    Rights & Interest of Advocates and Limitations thereof:\n\n    i.       The rights to practice\n    ii.      The right to argue his case\n    iii.     The right over his professional fees\n    iv.      The right to strike\n    v.       The right to take up teaching Law\n    vi.      The  limitations  of  the  rights  of  lawyers  including  restrictions  on  advertising,  bar  from\n             carrying on other professions, etc.\n    vii.     Restrictions on Senior Advocates\n\n    Module IV                                       (Lectures 6)\n\n    Standards of Professional Conduct and Etiquette\n\n    i.       Duty to the Court\n    ii.      Duty to the Client\n    iii.     Duty to the opponent\n    iv.      Duty towards Colleagues\n    v.       Duty in Imparting Training\n    vi.      Duty to render Legal Aid\n\n    Module V                                                (Lectures 8)\n\n    i.      Bench-Bar Relations\n ii.        Professional Misconduct and relevant case laws with special reference to the Contempt\n            of Court Act 1971.\niii.        Legal Ethics in Present Era\n    iv.     Impact of Globalization on the legal profession\n\n    Suggested Readings:\n\n    1.  Raju  Ramachandran,  Professional  Ethics:  Changing  Profession  and  Changing  Ethics\n        (Lexis Nexis, Butterworths).\n    2.  P. Ramanatha Aiyer, Legal & Professional Ethics – Legal Ethics, Duties & Privileges of\n        a Lawyer (Wadhwa Publications, Nagpur).\n    3.  D.V. SubbaRao, Sanjiva Row’s The Advocates Act, 1961(LexisNexis, Butterworths).\n    4.  Justice V. R. Krishna Iyer, Law, Lawyers and Justice (B. R. Publishing Corpn, Delhi).\n\n\n=== Page 206 ===\n5.  Dr.  Kailash  Rai,  Legal  Ethics,  Accountancy  for  Lawyers  and  Bench  Bar  Relations,\n    Central Law Publications.\n6.  Yashomati Ghosh, Legal Ethics and the Profession of Law (Lexis Nexis Buttersworth).\n7.  Raju  Ramchandran,  Professional  Ethics  for  Lawyers:  Changing  Profession  Changing\n    Ethics (Lexis Nexis).\n8.  Nicolson and Webb, Professional Legal Ethics (OUP).\n\nEssential Case Law\n1.  A.M. Mathur v. Pramod Kumar Gupta 1990 (2) SCC 533.\n2.  An Advocate v. Bar Council of India, 1989 Supp (2) SCC 25.\n3.  Anees Ahmed v. University of Delhi, AIR 2002 Del. 440.\n4.  Bar Council of Maharashtra v. M.V. Dabhulkar 1976 (2) SCR 48.\n5.  Bhupinder Kumar Sharma v. Bar Assn., Pathankot, (2002) 1 SCC 470 25.\n6.  C. Ravichandran Iyer v. Justice A.M. Bhattacharjee, (1995) 5 SCC 457.\n7.  Ex-Capt. Harish Uppal v. Union of India, (2003) 2 SCC 45.\n8.  Indian Council of Legal Aid v. Bar Council of India, AIR 1995 SC 691.\n9.  P.D. Gupta v. Ram Murti, (1997) 7 SCC 147 20.\n10. R.D. Saxena v. Balram Prasad Sharma, (2000) 7 SCC 264 6 22.\n11. Salil Dutta v. T.M. and M.C. (P) Ltd. (1993) 2 SCC 185 17.\n12. State of Maharashtra v. Budhikota Subbarao, (1993) 3 SCC 71.\n13. T.C. Mathai v. District & Sessions Judge, Thiruvananthapuram, (1999) 3 SCC 614 21.\n14. Vikas Deshpande v. Bar Council, AIR 2003 SC 309.\n\n\n=== Page 207 ===\nSemester IX\nLB-902                                                          Credits: 04\nSubject: Drafting, Pleading and Conveyancing             (Minimum Lectures: 40)\n\nCourse Objective\n\n     By  the  art  of  legal  drafting)  we  mean  the  art  of  composing  or  writing  all  documents\nwhich  are  either  expressly  intended  to  be,  or  which  frequently  become  the  subject  of  legal\ninterpretation.  The  Paper Drafting, Pleading and Conveyancing has  been  included  in  the\nsyllabus  with  a  view  to  equip  the  students  with  legal  drafting  abilities,  legal  frame  work\npertaining  to  the  appearances  before  various  tribunals  quasi  judicial  bodies  and  the  basic\nunderstanding of the principles of pleadings. For this purpose, the course contents of this study\nmaterial  have  been  so  designed  as  to  provide  practical  orientation  and  develop  necessary\nacumenship in drafting legal documents.\n\nCourse Outcome\nThis course is designed to create among the students:\n 1.  Analyze  and  define  the  concept  of  Pleading  and  various  rules  of  pleading  and  able  to\n     handle the client during the course of interaction.\n 2.  Articulate the argumentation process and apply the legal drafting abilities during the\n     appearances before Court and Tribunals\n 3.  Recognize  the  way  to  move  to  the  criminal  justice  system  with  aid  of  various\n     complaints.\n 4.  Identify and discuss the various forms of conveyancing deed such as sale deed,\n     gift, mortgage etc.\n 5.  Apply legal drafting skills and understand practical aspect of registration of such\n     documents.\n\nModule I - Criminal                                                       (Lectures - 10)\n\n     i.     General principles of drafting in the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.\nii.         First Information Report\n   iii.     Complaint\n    iv.     Framing of Charges\n     v.     Application relating to dispensation of parties and witnesses\n    vi.     Bail Application\n   vii.     Criminal Revision\n  viii.     Criminal Appeal\n\nModule II - Civil                                                           (Lectures - 10)\n\ni.         General principles of Pleadings in Code of Civil Procedure, 1908\nii.        Plaint\n\n\n=== Page 208 ===\niii.     Written Statement\n             iv.     Interlocutory Applications\n          v.         Original Petition\n             vi.     Execution Petition\n            vii.     Memorandum of Civil Appeal\nviii.                Civil Revision\nix.                  Petition under Article 226 of The Constitution of India.\n          x.          Petition under Article 32 of The Constitution of India.\n\nModule III - Conveyancing Part – 1                                               (Lectures - 10)\n\n    i. Agreements\nModule IV - Conveyancing Part – 2                                                (Lectures - 10)\n\n          i.        Sale Deed\nii.                 Mortgage Deed\n      iii. N.          -     Pleading, Drafting & Conveyancing\n                    2. Kafaltiya, A. B.           -     Pleading, Drafting & Conveyancing\n                    3. They will\nlearn  to  access  the  online  resources  as  well  as  other  library  resources  in  their  research.  The\nstudent will be able to write a research project on any given topic.\n\nModule I                                                             (Lectures - 10)\n\n1.     Research: meaning, objectives and significance\n2.     Criteria of Good Research\n3.     Various kinds of research: qualitative, quantitative, doctrinal, and non-doctrinal.\n\nModule II                                                            (Lectures - 10)\n\n1.     Legal Research and its types\n2.     Research process\n3.     Legal materials\n\nModule III                                                           (Lectures - 10)\n\n1.     Use of internet in research\n2.     Searching the library catalogue\n3.     Citation\n\nModule IV                                                            (Lectures - 10)\n\n1. How to Research (Buckingham: Open University Press).\n       ISBN: 0-335-19452-4\n2.     Buckley,  P  &  D  Clark.  Rough  guide  to  the  Internet  (London:  Rough  Guides). ISBN: 1-84174-029-2\n\n\n=== Page 210 ===\nSemester IX\nLB-905                                                        Credits-4\nSubject: Human Rights and Humanitarian Law                    (Minimum Lectures 40)\n\nCourse Objective\n\n            Human Rights are rights inherent to all human beings whatever our nationality, place of\nbirth ,class, caste, creed, sex, origin, colour, religion, language or any other status. Objective of\nthe  course  is  to  provide  knowledge  to  students  regarding  the  meaning  and  concept  of  human\nrights and its historical development till date. It also deals with the role of international statutory\nbodies in the protection of human rights and the provisions in Indian Constitution and domestic\nlaws  for  the  protection  of  human  rights.  The  course  is  designed  to  cover  the  concept  of\nHumanitarian  law  and  the  various  national  and  international  agencies  for  the  protection  of\nhuman rights.\n\nCourse Outcome\n\n            The  Course  will  enable  the  student  to develop  a strong  understanding  of  human  rights\nlaw  at  domestic,  regional  and  international  levels.  The  student  can  apply  the  knowledge  of\nhuman rights to their respective fields of work, be it academics, policy makers or activists.\n\nModule I-                                                     (Lectures-10)\n\ni.          Definition of Human Rights : Meaning and Concept.\n ii.        History and Development of Human Rights: Ancient, Medieval and Modern times.\niii.        Sources of Human Rights Law\niv.         Human Values: Liberty, Equality and Justice.\nv.          Human Rights and Indian Constitution\n\nModule II-                                                    (Lectures-10)\n\ni.          United Nations Charter and Human Rights.\n ii.        Universal Declaration of Human Rights, 1948\niii.        International Covenants on Human Rights:\n             a)  International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR), 1966\n             b)  International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights (ICESC), 1966\niv.         Regional Conventions on Human Rights\n\nModule III-                                                   (Lectures-10\n\n        i.  Implementation of Human Rights\n             a)  International Human Rights Council\n             b)  Human Rights Committee (CCPR) under ICCPR\n             c)  Committee on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights (CESCR) under ICESCR.\nii.     Protection of Human Rights Act, 1993.\n\n\n=== Page 211 ===\na)        National Human Rights Commission\n b)        State Human Rights Commissions\n\nModule IV-                                                            (Lectures-10)\n\ni.         Introduction to International Humanitarian law.\n ii.       History and development of International Humanitarian Law.\niii.       War Crimes and Crimes against Humanity\niv.        Vulnerable groups and human rights.\n\nSuggested Readings\n\n        1.  Alston, Phillip- The United Nations and Human Rights, Clarendon Press, London, 1995.\n        2.  Basu, D.D – Human Rights in Constitutional Law, Prentice Hall, New Delhi, 1994.\n        3.  S.K.Kapoor- Human  Rights under International and Indian  Law, Central Law Agency,\n            Allahabad, 1999.\n        4.  Paramjit  S. Its  also  covers  the  subject  relating  to  statutory  bodies  established  for  the\nprevention of crime and punishment and reformation of criminals. The course includes concept\nof punishment and its forms and concept of Capital Punishment and also Parole and Probation\nof offenders in India and other countries of World.\n\nCourse Outcome\n\nThe  student  will  be  able  to  understand  the  concept  of  Crimes,its  causes  and  various\nforms of crime. They can analyse the relevancy and adequacy of various forms of Punishment\nPtrescribed by Indian law, The Prison system in India and reforms needed if any.\n\nModule I-                                                  (Lectures-10)\ni.       Definition of Criminology\n ii.     Concept of Crimes : Social, Psychological and legal Approaches.\niii.     Nature and Scope of Criminology.\niv.      Relevance of Criminology to Contemporary Society.\nModule II-                                                               (Lectures-10\n i. Socio-Economic Crimes\n             a)  White collar Crimes\n             b)  Drug Abuse\n             c)  Crimes against Women and Children\n iii.    Sociological Theory of Crime\n\nModule III-                                                (Lectures-10)\n i.      Punishment : Concept and Theories\n ii.     Deterrent Theory\n iii.    Retributive Theory\n iv.     Preventive Theory\n v.      Reformative Theory\n vi.     Forms of Punishment and Judicial Sentences.\n vii. Capital punishment\n\n\n=== Page 213 ===\nModule IV-                                                        (Lectures-10)\n i.      Prison Administration\n ii.     Concept of Open Prison\n iii.    Parole and Probation of offenders\n iv.     Custodial Violence and Prison Reforms.\n\nSuggested Readings-\n\n1. Sutherland and Crssey – Principles of Criminology\n2. Aware  of  the  medical  technicalities  and  peculiarities  while  dealing  with  medico-legal\n                   cases.\n           2.      Have heightened awareness, consciousness and sensitivity about ethics in the healthcare\n                   laws and procedures.\n\n   Module-I Objective and Introduction                                     (Lectures: 08)\n\n           i. Injuries by Mechanical Violence: Introduction, Business & Contusions, Abrasions,\n                   Wounds, Introduction to Fire Arms & ammunitions.\n           iv.     Medico-Legal aspect of Wounds: Nature of injury, Examination of Injured Persons,\n                   Cause of Death from Wounds, Power of Volitional acts after receiving a fatal injury,\n                   Difference between wounds inflicted during life & after\n           v.      Difference between Suicidal, Homicidal & Accidental Wounds\n\n\n=== Page 215 ===\nModule- IV\nInsanity in its Medico-Legal Aspects:                              (Lectures: 08)\ni.       a, Introduction, Cause of Mental ill Health, Indication of Mental Health, Classification\n         of Mental Diseases, Feigned Mental ill health, Criminal Responsibility\n ii.       "content": "Suggested Readings:\n 1.      Modi: Medical Jurisprudence\n 2.      Indian Evidence Act,1872 (relevant sections)\n\n\n=== Page 216 ===\nSemester IX\nLB-9063                                                   Credit: 04\nSubject: Law, Science and Technology                      (Minimum Lectures- 40\nCourse Objectives\n\nAs science and technology assume central roles in our lives, economy, and legal system,\nthe  intersection  of  law  and  science  is  uniquely  positioned.This  course  is  designed  to  create\nawareness  amongst  the  studentsto  addressessentially  problems  and  to  address  the  remedial\nmeasures  of  science  and  technology  through  Law  as  an  instrument  to  promote  and  balance\ndevelopment and innovation. Further, it aims to create awareness in the minds of students and\ntaught  to  explore  and exploit  the  significance  of  scienceand  technology  and  to bring  it  within\nthe framework of law.It  further seeks to explore some specific aspects and to test the possible\ninteractions, controversies and their interrelationships.\n\nCourse Outcome\n\ni.  To  create  awareness  amongst  students  with  regards  to  legal developments  in  the  context  of\nemerging technology and science across various fields.\nii.  To  familiarize  students  with  problems  and  perspectives  between  law,  science  and  various\nforms of evolving technologies.\niii.  To  enable  students  to  understand  the  realm  of  privacy  evolving  with  developments  in\ntechnology.\niv.  To  understand  the  needs  for  legal  framework  and  regulatory  control  of  science  and\ntechnology.\nv. To study these aspects so as to strike a balance between essential principles of human rights,\nsustainable development,ethics, etc., withscience and technology at the same time.\n\nModule I                                                         (Lectures: 10)\n\nIntroduction\n     i.     .Emergence of Technology and Industrial Revolution\n  ii.       The need for legal control of Science and Technology\n iii.       Science & Technology vis-a-vis Sustainable and equitable development\niv.         Impact of Human Rights on Science & Technology\n     v.     Law, Ethics and Technology\n\nModule II                                                        (Lectures: 10)\n1 . E-Commerce\ni.         Salient features of E-Commerce and its advantages and disadvantages\nii.        Model Law of E-Commerce\niii. Jurisdiction Issue in E-Commerce\niv.        E-payment and E-Banking\n2. .       E-Contracting\ni.         Salient features of E-contract\nii.        Formation of E-contract and types\n\n\n=== Page 217 ===\niii. E-mail Contracting\niv. Indian Approach on E-contract\n3. . Digital signature and Electronic Signatureand Data Protection\ni.       Digital signature and Electronic Signature and Data Protection\nii.      Electronic Governance - Concept of electronic records and electronic signatures\niii.      Creation and authentication of digital signature: Concept of electronic signature certificates\niv. Certification authorities and their role\n\nModule III                                                                   (Lecture:10)\n1.       Privacy, Law and Technology\ni.       Origin and Development of Law of Privacy\nii.      Concept and Nature and Law of Privacy\niii. Law of Privacy vis-a-vis Science and Technology\n\n2.       Cyberspace, Technology and Law Law\ni.       Jurisdictional issues in cyber law: Types of jurisdiction and the test evolved\nii.      Jurisdiction under IT Act, 2008.\niii. Cyber Crimes& Legal Framework with specific focus on offences under IT Act, 2008.\n\nModule IV                                                                    (Lectures: 10)\n1. Law and Genetic Technologies\ni.        Introduction: Genetic Technologies\nii.       Genetic Engineering and Plant Variety Act\niii.     Natural Resources and Bio-Diversity Act\n2..      Law and Medical Technologies\n         i.  Medical  Technologies  and  Forensic  Science:  DNA  Profiling,  Brain  Mapping,Narco-\n         analysis\n         ii.         Medical Technologies and Drugs: Patent Protection, Life Saving Drugs, Generic Drugs\n         and National Drugs Policies\n         iii.      Medical  Technologies  and  New  Areas:  Organ  Transplantation,Experiment  on  Human\n         Beings, Sex Determination Test,Cloning, Artificial Reproductive Technologies\n3. Law and Bio Technology\n        i.Origin and Development of Bio Technology\n        ii.Debatable issues in biotechnological innovations\n        iii.Ethical and Moral implications on the use of Genetic Engineering\n\nSuggested Readings:\n1) MarkandeyKatju, Law in scientific Era (2000) Universal, New Delhi\n2) Cees J.Hamelink, the ethics of cyber space(2001) Sage.\n3) JonhZinian et.al(ed) World of Science and Rule of Law (1986) Oxford\n4) U.Baxi,Biotechnology and Legal Order: Dilemmas of the Future of Law and Human nature\n(1993)\n5. Vakul Sharma, Information Technology Law and Practice,  Universal Law Publishers, 2011\n(3rd Edn)\n\n\n=== Page 218 ===\n6. Harish Chander, Cyber Laws and IT Protection, PHI Learning Pvt. Ltd., 2012\n7.  Nandan  Kamath,  Law  Relating  to  Computers,  Internet  and  Ecommerce,  Universal  Law\nPublishing Co., Ltd., 2006.\n8. Bernard E. Rollin, Science and Ethics, Cambridge University Press, 2006.\n9.  Arvind  Kumar,  Gobind  Das,  Biodiversity,  Biotechnology  and  International  Knowledge:\nUnderstanding Intellectual Property Rights, Narosa Book Distributors Pvt. Ltd., 2010\n10.  Jaiprakash  G.  Shevale,  Forensic  DNA  Analysis:  Current  Practices  and  Emerging\nTechnologies, 2013\n11.  Lori  B.  Andrews,  Maxwell  J.  Mehlman,  Mark  A. Justice YatindraSingh,Cyber Laws, Universal Law Publishing Co, New Delhi, (2012).\n16.SudhirNaib, The Information Technology Act, 2005: A Handbook, OUP, New York, (2011).\n\n\n=== Page 219 ===\nSemester IX\nLB-9064                                                                   Credits- 04\nSubject: Gender And Law                                      (Minimum Lectures: 40)\n\nCourse Objective\n\nThis course focuses on gender policies in law. The main objective is to learn how law and legal\ninstitutions are mobilized as arenas for structuring, challenging and transforming gender norms,\nidentities and roles.\n\nCourse Outcome\n\nThe students will be able to understand the gender equality.\n\nModule–I: Sources of Law                                                  (Lectures -10)\n\ni.       Introduction\nii.      Primary Sources\niii.     Socio political Philosophy and Law\niv.      Religion, Custom and Conventions\nv.       Secondary Sources\nvi.      The Constitutions, Statutes and Judicial decisions\n\nModule- II: Gender Equality and Constitution                 (Lectures- 10)\n\ni.       Preamble: Political Rights, Economic Rights and Social Justice\nii.      Fundamental Rights\niii.     Directive Principles of state Policy\niv.      Uniform Civil Code\nv.       Fundamental Duties\nvi.      Women’s Representation in Local Bodies\n\nModule -III: Understanding Gender and Law                                 (Lectures- 10)\n\ni.       Concept of Gender\nii.      Historical Background of Gender\niii.     Position of Gender in the Perspective Modern era\niv.      Gender violence & Gender Discrimination\nv.       Gender Neutral Laws\nvi.      Gender and legal System\n\nModule - IV: Women Welfare Laws                                           (Lectures-10)\n1. The Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961\n2. Cyber Crime and Victimization of Women\n7. Labour Welfare Legislations: Maternity Benefit Act, Factories Act, Equal\nRemuneration Act,\n8. The Prevention of Acid Attacks and Rehabilitation of Acid Attack Victims Bills, 2017\n\nSuggested Readings:\n\n1.  Women and Social Reforms in Modern India Sumit Sarkar &Tanika Sarkar\n2. Reddy\n\n\n=== Page 221 ===\nSemester-X\n\n\n=== Page 222 ===\nSemester-X\nLB-1001                  Compulsory Paper\nSubject: Dissertation    Credits: 12\n\nSemester-X\nLB-1002               Compulsory Paper\nSubject: Viva Voce    Credits: 04\n\nSemester-X\nLB-1003                         Compulsory Paper\nSubject: Aid Clinic programs    Credits: 04\n\n\n=== Page 223 ===\nOptional Paper\nSemester-X\nLB-10031                                                                        Credits: 04\nSubject: Socio-Economic Offences                           (Minimum Lectures 40)\n\nCourse Objective\nThe  objective  of  socio-economic  Affiance  is  to  enhance  the  awareness  in  society  regarding  the\ngravity  of  these  offences  in  comparison  to  Traditional  offences.  The  Blackmarketing,  hoarding,\ncorruption, caste based mob lynching, harassment at workplace etc ; are the much heinous crimes\nthan traditional offences which affects society at large. Therefore, this paper has been incorporated\nin BBA.LLB. (H) Syllabus.\n\n Module - I:                                                         (Lectures-10)\n   i.     Concept and Nature of socio economic offences,\n  ii.     Distinction between traditional offences and socio-economic offences.\n\n Module - II:                                                        (Lectures-10)\n  i.      Domestic Violence\n  ii.     The Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012.\n\n Module - III:                                                       (Lectures-10)\n  i.      White Collar Crimes\n  ii.     Anti Corruption Laws\n\n Module - IV:                                                        (Lectures-10)\n   i.     The Indecent Representation of Women (Prohibition) Act, 1986\n  ii.     The Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, 1989\n\nSuggested Reading\n\n  1.     Sutherland and Crssey - Criminology\n  2.     Mahesh Chandra, Socio- Economic Offences (1979)\n  3.     J.S.P. Singh, Socio- Economic Offences (1st Ed., 2005, Reprint 2015)\n  4.     Ahmed Siddiqui, Criminology: Problems and Perspectives (4th Ed., 1997)\n  5.     T.V. Nawal, Legally Combating Atrocities against SC and ST, (2004)\n  6.     Lawyers  Collective  (Ed. by  Indira  Jaising), Handbook on Law of Domestic Violence,\n         (1stEd., 2009)\n  7.     Ghosh, Srikanta; Economic Offences Universal’s – Socio Economic Offences Law\n\n\n=== Page 224 ===\nSemester-X\nLB-10033                                                                         Credit: 04\nSubject: Media Law                                                           (Minimum Lectures: 40)\n\nCourse Objectives\nThis course seeks to draw from the co-relationship of the quintessential Constitutional objective\nof free speech and expression, and existing Rights and Restrictions governing the fourth estate,\nthe media. Media being a wider term, the course seeks to covers the various aspects of the law\nrelating  to  the  Press,  dissemination  of  information,  both  commercial  and  non-commercial  in\nnature,  advertising,  broadcasting,  the  cinema  and  such  emerging  jurisprudence,  trends  and\nplatforms which are essential to fully appreciate the dimensions of media and law.\n\nCourse Outcomes\n      ∑       To  create  amongst  students  an  understanding  of  the  relevant  constitutional  freedoms,\n              legal issues and ethical principles pertaining to press and media.\n      ∑       To  understand  the  legal  framework  that  is  shaping  the  convergence  of  old  media\n              industries and the emergence of new ones.\n      ∑       To appraise students with how the law is shaped, including the delicate balancing with\n              changing dimensions of time and social values.\n      ∑       To  help  students  recognize  and  assert  their  legal  right  of  freedom  of  speech  and\n              expression,  privacy  and  at  the  same  time  analyse  the  restrictions,  including  the\n              regulatory frameworks and to apply the same to emerging media.\n      ∑       To  familiarize  students  with  the  major  principles  of  media  law  while  examining  the\n              important court decisions and statutory enactments therein.\nModule I                                                                         (Lectures-6)\n\nMedia and Law: An Introduction\n\n      i.      Meaning and Types of Media\n   ii.        Theories related with Media\n  iii.        Effect Theories related with Media\niv.           Importance of Media\n      v.      Historical  background  of  Freedom  of  Speech  and  Expression  in  India  with  special\n              reference to Print Media\nModule II                                                                    (Lectures-12)\n\n1.            Constitutional framework of freedom of Speech and expression in India\n   ii.        Meaning and development of freedom of Speech and expression\n  iii.        Constitutional status of Media\niv.           Facets of Media under Article 19(1)(a) of Right to circulate, Right to criticize, Right to\n              conduct  interviews,  Right  to  express  beyond  national  boundaries,  Publication  of\n              parliamentary proceedings\n2.           Constitutional Restrictions on freedom of Speech and expression\n      i.      The sovereignty and integrity of India\n      ii.     The Security of the State\n\n\n=== Page 225 ===\niii.         Friendly relations with Foreign States\niv.          Public Order\n      v.     Decency or Morality\nvi.          Contempt of Court\nvii.         Defamation or incitement to an offence\nModule III                                                             (Lectures-10)\n\n1.          Right to Privacy\n      i.     Defining and origin of Privacy\n   ii.       Privacy and the Right to freedom of Speech and expression\n  iii.       The law on Privacy in India\n2.     Right to Information\n      i.     Laws that License Secrecy\n   ii.       Judicial recognition of the Right to Information\n  iii. Indian Environmental Law\n1.General Course Information: the paper of Indian Environmental Law is\n  open for the students of first semester under choice based credit system of\n  the university.\n  1.1 Name of the course: Indian Environmental Law\n  1.2 Code: ML-OG- (EL) 102\n  1.3 Credit: 04\n2.Course objective:\n  Since the inception of human history, environment has played a vital role\n  in sustaining life and catering to the needs of human beings.However in\n    due course of time man has been swayed by the desire of greater\n  inustrialization, urbanization, modernizatinultiately at the cos  e\n eent. In su  iatin he oleatal ovents,\n of individuals and that of society towards environment protection has\nbecome very important. Therefore, today Environmental Law is one of\n  the most important tools for environment protection and management and\n        hence it is necessary for every student to understand this\nmultidisciplinary subject.\n  In this context, the Department of Law, SLS, Babasaheb Bhimrao\nAmbedkar University, Lucknow proposes to launch an academic program\nin CBCS titled 'Indian Environmental Law'.\n2.2 Course Outcomes:\n\nScanned with CamScanner\n\n\n=== Page 240 ===\nT\n    designed to create among the students-\n\n    environmental issues.\n\n    Cto  o  en n\n      nin\n\n    evolution of different principles.\n\n    of environment.\n\n                                       an  evetio viental pouo  o\n    environment.\n                                                      S   e  o\n    pow  enal overent n overnment  k\n    Environment Tribunals.\n\n    2.Syllabus:\n    Module-I\nMeaning and concept of Environment, Constitutional Provisions related\n   to environmental protection, Environmental rights under common law\n    principles, Environmental rights as human rights.\n    Module-II\n  Legal regime of pollution control-water pollution and air pollution\n   control-specific legislations, Environment (Protection) Act, 1986,\n    National Green Tribunal Act, 2010\n    Module-III\n\n                                          Scanned with CamScanner\n\n\n=== Page 241 ===\nNoise pollution regulation, Nuclear and Radiation Pollution, Judicial\n    Response and environment protection.\nModule-IV\n   Public Insurance Liability Act, 1991, Hazardous wastes management\n    regulation, Environment Impact Assessment Law.\n\n  3. General Course Information: the paper of Indian Cyber Crimes is open\n for the students of first semester under choice based credit system of the\n university.\n 1.1 Name of the course: CYBER CRIMES\n 1.2 Code: ML-OG-(CL) 403                                                  DINOS\n 1.3 Credit: 04\n1.4 Course Objective:\n The development imaton tecology hoved 4\n communication, has facilitated the growth of trade and commerce and .                  *\n overall has made lie comfortable and. At the same time, the global reach              1\n of the Internet, the low marginal cost of online activity, and the relative           .\n   anonymity of users have contributed to a wide escalation in cybercrimes.            2\n       This course provides an overview of cybercrime and the cyber law\n practices put in place to respond to them.                                1000\n   The aim of this paper is to acquaint the students with the significance of Cyber    )\n space and to highlight the various legal, social and national issues pertaining to    6111\n the breach and commission of offence in cyber space thus creating the basic\n clarity and understanding of cybercrimes and cyber security laws in India.\n The paper is limited in scope to laws governing the aforesaid issues to India\nonly. U.S.A. France and India.\nRule of Law changing dimensions, Classification of Administrative Actions.\nNatural Justice in Administrative Actions\nModule-III                                                       02 credits\nRule Making Powers of the Administration , Delegated legislation- problems,\nprocess and control, comparative approaches, Constitutionality of delegated\nlegislation., Requirement for the validity of delegated legislation.   "completed_sections": [
    "Below is a detailed analytical reading of the provided document section. The material comprises university-level administrative communication and meeting records related to revising the MCA (Master of Computer Applications) and related programs to incorporate MOOC-based courses (SWAYAM) into the curriculum.\n\n1) What the document is and its scope\n- Origin and context:\n  - The primary material is from Babasaheb Bhimrao Ambedkar University Lucknow (BBAU). The header shows the institution name and a formal notification dated 19 June 2020 (Letter No 844 BRA20).\n  - The core issue is governance around the integration of MOOC-based content into the department’s academic programs, specifically the Department of Computer Science and the MCA program, with dates around mid- to late-2020.\n- Content type:\n  - A formal university notification about placement of departmental committee minutes and school-level minutes for governance purposes.\n  - An emergent (ad hoc) meeting notice regarding the revision of course structure to incorporate MOOC courses.\n  - Minutes from the emergent BPGS (Board of Postgraduate Studies) meeting.\n  - Annexures (A, B, C) that include the detailed internal minutes and the revised course structure syllabi.\n  - A set of course descriptions/papers for the MCA program across different years/semesters, including MOOC-enabled elective options sourced from SWAYAM.\n\n2) Key policy intention and decisions\n- MOOC integration objective:\n  - To incorporate MOOC courses (from the SWAYAM portal) into the official syllabus of the department’s programs (notably MCA and M.Tech CS).\n  - The abstracted decision is to allocate up to 20% of the syllabus/topics per program as MOOC-based content.\n- Governance and workflow:\n  - A department-level committee will identify suitable MOOC courses to be offered in a given semester.\n  - The committee will finalize the list of MOOC papers well before the semester starts.\n  - Students will be required or allowed to register for MOOC courses via the SWAYAM portal, with the department’s MOOC coordinator overseeing registration and progress.\n  - MOOC-based courses are to be integrated with regular curricular structure, and the department may designate some of these MOOC courses as Open Electives (or similar) with credits aligning to the CBCS (Choice-Based Credit System) framework.\n  - Evaluation and certification arising from MOOC courses are to be integrated into the student’s overall assessment, with the MOOC coordinator playing a central coordinating role.\n- Effective timeline:\n  - The emergent meeting and annexures indicate an intent to implement for the 2020-2021 academic year, with MOOC topics to be incorporated into MCA and CS programs.\n  - The notification cites prior communications: an email from the Dean, Academic (dated 28/05/2020) and a university notification (817/8BAU/2020, dated 16/06/2020) guiding MOOC incorporation.\n\n3) Structure and contents by section (with observations about the text)\n- Page 72 (Notification section):\n  - Purpose: Request to Heads of Departments to place DR(C) Minutes and BPGS Minutes before relevant governance bodies, and to place School Board Minutes before the Academic Council for approval.
